text:
@David Mead Close to no emission is not true. Here in Europe we rely a lot on diesel passenger cars and they do have less CO2 emission comparing to petrol (gasoline),  but they have other worse emissions (DieselGate). Now with introducing of Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF, AdBlue) in most passenger Diesel Cars those emissions are down about 95% but still not zero. 


Now to this video -  those Start/Stop systems (that EE also reviewed) are major backdoor for manufacturers to lower those emissions in the vehicle's data sheet. The Previous NEDC test cycle was a joke. And those Start/Stop systems abused it. With the new WLTP things are better but still not good enough. Those systems actually (as EE told)  do not work efficiently for fast stops (less than 7-10 seconds, depending on the car) . So moving in a traffic jam before a roundabout or some other situations (that in Europe are a lot) that you stop your car, wait a couple of seconds (less than 7-10)  and move again, that system uses more fuel thus more CO2 and other emissions. That system is mandatory turned ON when a car is started, as it is regulated and tested in that way, so most users use it. Other users turn OFF the system every time, not because of the environment but for discomfort (especially in diesel cars as starting there is more noticeable). Also this system works when specific criterias are met. In example does not work when the car is cold on cold weather with the heater ON or when it is hot and you put your AC on max, or your battery is low on power, or the secondary battery is low on power (after 5-7-10 consecutive stops it will not work in most cars) or it stops working in middle of the stop cycle because of those criterias. So you actually do not know when this system will benefit in real life and one thing for sure it will not work for a 100% of the time it is expected to. So the car will 100% not reach those CO2 emission for the entire life of the vehicle. With full electric this 7-10 seconds do not matter, with hybrid pretty much the same. Then there is "Flaring" which is the controlled burning of natural gas and a common practice in oil/gas exploration if it would not be profitable to get that "waste product" natural gas to market. It starts up on petrol but after a few minutes it switches over to LPG (Liquified Petroleum Gas) which produces between 40-60% less co2. Coupled with it already being 30 years old and still has plenty of life left in it, compare that to buying a new EV approximately every ten years. So to date, my one ICE has outlived THREE EVs. text:
This is a pretty in-depth method of attempting to sway a fickle, and often, deliberately obtuse public toward electric cars.
For most, the simplest way to understand things is that "pound for pound" as they say, operating an electric car is much less expensive in terms of "fuel."  Comparing acquisition costs is ridiculous and ignores the reality that early adopters of electric cars ARE going to pay a premium - just as all those who rush out to buy the latest iPhone, or Macbook, or 300 inch, super high density TV.  The basic components of an electric car are CHEAPER than a gasoline engine car.  The process of fabricating motors is "mature tech" going back well over 100 years and is far, FAR less intricate and complex than making the zillion or so parts in the modern ICE.  Then comes the MOST expensive part of a ICE car...that automatic transmission which has thousands of precious parts, with servos and actuators and sensors, wires, oil, and layers of precision cut gear sets that must be precisely assembled yet can so easily be destroyed in a few thousand miles in the hands of the American abuser-consumer.  By comparison an electric motor has ONE moving part.  The single-speed "transmission" is a fancy reference to a simple, planetary gear reduction to drive the wheels.  An electric car has no fuel system, no coolant hoses, no starter motor, no oil-filled crank-case, no oil-filled transmission, no spark plugs, no coil, no high-energy ignition system replete with wires and connectors.  No radiator, no need for antifreeze, no exhaust manifold, no catalytic converter, no mufflers, no Y-pipes, no EGRs and sensors, no complex feedback look ECM system to maximize fuel economy - which still sucks consider the basic engine is only 15% efficient at converting gasoline into motive power.
The so-called high cost of batteries is used to justify ripping off early adopters, and this allows the obtuse crowd to pretend buying an electric car is only about initial cost and how long it takes to offset the higher cost electric - usually comparing economy priced ICE cars to electrics.   On the other hand, compare the acquisition cost of what MOST idiots are out there splurging on - $60K trucks, and full-size SUVs, and $35-$70K sport sedans, and there is NO comparison to any electric.
The electric car driver gives up nothing in performance since a motor delivers full torque instantly.  An electric can also recover significant energy while decelerating. 

The other day I was calculating how much it cost for me to make my daily, 77 mile commute in my Kona electric compared to my wife's Santa Fe Limited and was stunned to discover that whereas my Kona cost a surprising $3.86 (Tier 1 PG&E) to go the distance, my wife's thirsty (but more fuel efficient than all the full-size trucks clogging the highways) Santa Fe cost $11.98!  That's a whopping 310 PERCENT MORE to drive just 77 miles!
Much is made of the fact that even a large battery pack such as the 64 kWh unit in the Kona electric is "only" equal to about 2 gallons of gasoline due to the lower energy density of a battery versus liquid gasoline, but another way of looking at it is that the Kona will go 300 miles on those "2 gallons of gas" while the wife's SUV will consume 12 or more gallons of gasoline.
Also, while nobody has any control of how gasoline is sourced - they must pay the price whatever it is.  ELECTRONS can be sourced from many different places!  Taking one's home solar drastically reduces grid usage, and adding a powerwall can make the average home electron "net positive" in that it NEVER pulls power from the grid!  Then, the cost to fuel one's electric car is "free" essentially.  Granted all this costs money, but people are going to convert to solar anyway, so adding an electric car makes MORE sense than adding yet another ICE car!

text:
Comparing 30kwh battery(which is somewhat small concidering Nissan is shoving a 40kwh battery in the Leaf with talk of a 62kwh one coming) towards the average "gas car" which, concidering you took the US as baseline is probably not at all in the same class is a bit meh. I assume a 30kwh electric car isn't the average electric car in the US either (you might find a smaller average in Europe though but it is still going to be a bigger car). If you were to compare the average CO2 output of a car the size of this theoretical 30kwh electric car, something like a VW Polo you might discover you need to drive your electric car for far longer to break even on CO2. You might even have trouble doing that at all in some states if you account for battery replacements over time.

The 100kwh comparison is a bit of a mixed bag fro me. I'd assume the average electric car would be somewhere in between so this could be biased towards the combustion engines somewhat. Then again, your average numbers come from the US where big gas guzzling pick up trucks are still a thing. :P Europe paints a different picture though. When for example they compared the average electric vs gas cars in Germany they concluded it would take around 100.000 km (62k miles) of driving on their 14.000km (8700 mile) a year average leading to a little over 7 years to break even. 


Now I'm not saying the electric car isn't better for emisions but this is a highly debated subject without one clear answer. If you do open the can of worms and dive deeper into the rabbit hole you'd have to take into account many things like the logistics of production (the old folktale of a hummer being more enviromentally friendly than a prius because it's parts were all made locally and didn't need to be shipped from all over the world for example). Logistics of the fuel (piping and shipping of oil and it's refinement impact). Different spare part usage between the cars and their related enviromental impact, different tyre wear due to electric cars being heavier, impending lithium shortages that may lead to limited use of batteries in other fields and 5000 orso other factors that all factor in to the question of "Is an electric car worse for the enviroment?". 
It really is impossible to truely answer this currently because we don't have all the data we would need. 

Interesting subject to do research on though but due to the limited scope and data of all research done into this so far this discussion is going to go on for a looooong time before we have one solid answer. The benefit of having cleaner air where it has the largest impact (in cities and such) may outweigh some other enviromental hazards elsewhere though.

text:
First of all, aren't there OTHER pollutants to take into consideration too? Like toxic materials used to make both, the lifespan and how much it will require and release in total? Secondly, I'd like a comparison with new, low consumption models of ICE cars, not the 'average' that includes super old cars, and heck, probably trucks and buses too! Finally, there's the usability issue, in its many aspects - first of all the obvious one about limited range and such, the cut on range in cold weather, the damages from cold charging and use in hot environments... Those all reduce the lifespan and efficiency of electric cars. Next is the question of practical application - how many electric cars can the electric grid in most countries sustain if we are to change now? Kind of the same as the 'solar problem' - the peak production hours of solar happen to be the hours when the need for electricity is the lowest, which is why we can make less use of it, this also comes down to how bad even our current batteries are as we can't really store electricity in any sustainable and efficient way.. But back to the topic - most people come back from work around the same time which, if we switch to electric, would create a huge spike load on the grid in those hours that the current electric grid in most places probably can't maintain. This could somewhat be offset by having chargers at workplaces, solar energy and solar panels on roofs, but i still have my doubts about how sustainable and possible it is right now for us to make a big shift to electric.. Hopefully there's a breakthrough soon in battery technology so both our cars and electric grids can properly benefit from solar, but for now, i still have my doubts..

text:
A 50 kwh battery in your house will only half charge a Tesla automobile at night.

The Tesla web site reports that four Powerwall modules (56 kwh) will set you back an estimate $27,900 for the hardware; not counting installation labor, permits and inspections and upgrades to your home wiring, if any are needed.

You will need a PV array with an output of about 14 kilowatts or greater to fully recharge the Powerwall modules in four hours of full sunlight during the winter.  Ten kilowatts is the minimum to directly operate a Tesla home charger from the PV panels.  That requires that you stay home during the day to recharge.

Fifty kwh will not suffice inside the Arctic Circle where the sun will not rise for up to six months during the winter.  Storage of up to 18,000 to 20,000 kwh, possibly more, is needed.  PV output of 200 kilowatt hours, or more, per day is needed to cover daily usage and to incrementally charge the battery back up for winter use.

 Not all locations are equal.  Some are still better than others even with storage.

text:
Not even Tesla uses Tesla Solar Panels to power Tesla Superchargers.  

Tesla-branded refueling facilities are located in areas which have commercial zoning.  Commercially zoned land is expensive to lease or to buy.  

It takes about four square meters (40 square feet) of of solar panels to produce 1 kilowatt of electrical power in full sunlight striking the solar panels perpendicularly.  It requires 4,800 square feet (0.11 acre) of solar panels to power one Tesla Supercharger at local solar noon.  Battery storage and additional area of solar panels is needed if operating hours are to extend beyond about 10 am to 2 pm local solar time.

The cost of nearby commercially zoned land quickly becomes prohibitive.

The area of solar panels can be reduced by use of battery storage if the number of customers are few.  The area of solar panels could be reduced to 300 square feet if there were only one customer every three or four days, or less frequently, and at least 100 to 120 kwh of storage is provided.  The customers are SOL if two show up at the same time or within three days of each other.

text: What myth?  I don't think many people at all believe that an electric car is worse for the environment than a gas powered car.  The real myth is that electric cars are significantly better for the environment than gas cars, which they aren't.  While there is some environmental benefit to electric over gas, you also have to take into account what you are giving up in range and speed by driving an electric car.  As you pointed out, the more range and speed your electric car has, the less environmental benefit it has. Someone looking to buy a green vehicle is more likely to purchase a new or newer vehicle, a more realistic comparison would be comparing new vehicles currently on the market. Regarding current vehicles on the market, in the model year 2016 (per the EPA) the average CO2 emissions of all vehicles was 359 grams/mile. Also worth noting, which is a side issue, but still relevant - whatever carbon emissions an electric car produces during use are located at the power plants producing the electricity, while for a petrol vehicle they happen at the location of the car itself.
So, electric vehicles would work wonders in improving air quality around cities, if nothing else, since vehicle emissions are pretty bad for that.

text:
Couple of oversights:
1) it is incorrect to compare the US gasoline fleet‚Äôs average emissions vs electric fleets average emissions, as those two fleets have a significantly different mix of vehicles
-the electric fleet is almost completely made of commuter sized 5-passenger cars
-the ICE fleet is a mix of small cars, trucks, and multi passenger vehicles
-it is far more accurate to compare model by model (I.e. leaf vs civic, model S vs Audi A5)

2) we should include carbon emissions for the production of gasoline: 3-7lbs per gal (5lbs/average) 

3) we should include line losses and charging efficiencies for the electric vehicle:
-line losses:3-13% (US avg: 6.5%)
-charging losses: 10% (240v) - 30%(110v)

So doing a comparison:  a Honda civic - a comparison to a leaf - emits 4.5 tons of CO2/year

A Nissan Leaf emits about 2.2 tons of CO2/year (US average, could be as high as 3.5 tons)

So given your example of ~4-5 tons CO2 to produce the battery, that gives the leaf a CO2 break even time of about 2 years and a 10 year carbon savings of about 18 tons - or about 30%

But this 30% increase in carbon efficiency comes at the cost of about 50% price premium - ($30000 for the leaf vs $20000 for the civic)
And at a reduction of available range down to 150 miles vs 400 (or unlimited) for the civic.

They're both new-wave pop, but very different, because they both had different takes on which direction they're taking the New Wave (And No-wave)  You have to take the entire system, from raw materials like the Phosphorus, or Magnesium used as a catalyst in the Lithium Ions to the point-pollution of the electical energy at it's source (A coal power-plant vs a Wind-farm)  To calculate the total impact on the environment of the car itself.  It's complicated, and false dichotomies like "Better for the environment" over-simplify by eliminating significant factors.  Like where the Catalysts, and Energy comes from.  Without cleaner sources of energy like Wind-farms to shut down Coal Power plants, it just moves the pollution off the street, and to the power plants.  (Not to mention the Rare Earth metal mining, and refining to build all those batteries.)

text:
This is well thought out.  However, there is one MASSIVE thing that electric car supporters forget.  If people started to switch to electric cars in volume, all of the equations change.  It takes time to find optimal locations for wind and solar.  Hydro dams alter the environment as well.  All of these can take time to build and meet with lots of resistance and cost quite a bit in terms of fossil fuel to build.  That means if we start to switch to electric cars in volume there are only 2 easy solutions to provide that electricity.  The first is to burn fossil fuels to make the electricity.  This negates the reason to buy an electric car.  The second is to make more nuclear plants.  Unfortunately, nuclear power mishaps (Three Mile Island, Chernobyl, Fukushima) make people resistant to this as well.
My point is that until people can decide on a way to significantly increase the production of electricity without burning fossil fuels, switching to electric cars remains a mistake.  However, it is a mistake made with good intentions.  Perhaps we can use those good intentions to pave a road somewhere. . . . .

text:
The high estimate is probably the most accurate.  Here's why.  You have to consider the generator to battery losses in charging process.  You have to produce more than 100kw at the power plant to fill the 100kw Tesla battery.  There are transmission losses to the charging station and losses in charging.  The closer you get to battery capacity the higher the losses.  There is virtually no energy lost from the pump to the fuel for petroleum powered cars.  I am neglecting the energy consumed to get the fuel to the pump or the power plant. Perhaps you could do a video calculate the energy required per btu for both fuel sources.

But wait there is more.  If you use renewables other than hydro you need continuous spinning backup consuming fuel in case it gets cloudy or the wind drop the wind gets to high since wind turbines operate in a range.  The duty cycle for renewalables is about 30% at best.  The only way you can reliably generate carbon free energy is nuclear.  So, while you will eventually break even it's going to be the long estimate.

text:
An excellent analysis by someone I consider unbiased. I am slightly biased against anything that comes from the Left side of politics but I am an engineer and I can go with the science or the math. I like how the analysis was done. My best guess is that it is roughly a break even proposition if one compares full electric only to full time combustion. Part of the reason is that you lose a lot of energy as you transfer forms, i.e. fossil fuel to electric through a generator then across a grid to an outlet. Through the outlet to the battery which is chemical energy which once again transforms to mechanical energy, i.e. motion. Here are the numbers, I found:
burning fossil fuel to get useable heat - about 85% (running a gas-fired water heater, or making steam to power a turbine...some heat goes up the smokestack). 
burning fossil fuel to get electricity - about 33% 
sunlight to electricity in a PV cell - about 10% (sunlight is at least free but unreliable and less useable at northern latitudes)
putting electrical energy into a battery (charging it) and pulling it back out: about 90% 
converting electrical energy into mechanical energy with an electric motor about 85% 
To be fair one has to go past the production of vehicles to the production and transport of energy. We will say that vehicle production is roughly a wash in producing a car with a combustion engine to one with electrical. However, gasoline has to be transported to stations everywhere which takes rails, trucks and pipelines, much less storage. So, fuel to a power plant only is more efficient and then out over a boosted grid to your home and selected recharging stations. This is where electricity should win. You virtually eliminate the transportation and storage but only at the station level. You hook up millions of vehicle to the electric grid and you will have a new problem and huge power demands so power demand would have to ramp up quickly which means more fuel, even coal to power plants versus gas stations. It should still net out very well.

What cannot be done is the elimination of combustion engines for a host of reasons. What should also be avoided is the idea that fossil fuels are "evil". You have to look at what came before. Before modern power grids people burned raw coal, heating oils, wood and dung. All of these are far worse and less efficient and less reliable that what we have now. The old homes in NJ often still had coal bins or storage for heating oil. So, rather than calling Exxon or Sinclair or others evil understand they are what allowed us to escape the Middle Ages and live in temperature controlled homes and ultimately extend our lifespans. Even the kings of old did not have this.

text:
So it's more ecological as long as you only mine lithium in the Mad Max's back yard? How much 'middle of nowhere' do you think is really available before you start poisoning & displacing people? Scale matters here. Maybe you could safely mine enough lithium for tens of thousands of EV's, but how about tens of millions of EV's? And after 20 years of making tens of millions of EV's/year, how much more difficult then? Where do you put it when its worn out? Also, how much Nickle and Cobalt is actually available? We think of aluminum as fairly common, but building the ISS actually raised global aluminum prices, because there's a finite supply. How safe is Cobalt? Cobalt is not safe to touch or breath the air near it... and most of the cobalt mining is done in the 3rd world without any regard for the poor and children working in the mines. If the mines were not using humans as disposable fodder, how much more would the materials cost in dollars and emissions to produce? And that's at current production levels. Is there even enough lithium & cobalt available to be mined to sustain a very large EV based auto industry long term? This video takes a kinda superficial approach to these issues.

Also, assigning the car production a fake number does matter. If the production cost in CO emissions is significantly higher than 10k tons, then the raw % difference in emissions will be a far less significant part of the equation. Most cars are $3000-$5000 worth of raw material, expanded in price by the cost in energy and labor to make them into a car. If a car costs $50,000, and you spend (or don't spend) $2000/year to power it, you'll have to drive it for a very very long time to burn enough petroleum to equal the amount of energy expended making the car. Which is why "fuel cost" over the life of a car is only a fraction of the overall cost of car ownership. And while cost and carbon emissions are not the same thing, in the industrialized world, they are somewhat linked.

Until large-sheet graphene becomes available and cost effective (as in, so long as we are stuck with lithium ion battieries) EV's can only be a limited segment of the automotive marketplace before they suffer crippling issues of supply & demand problems in terms of raw materials, and ecological & humanitarian harm. Graphene though is made from carbon, the only trick is getting it into a molecular shape it doesn't naturally prefer. With (affordable) graphene batteries (should that become something we can accomplish), you could see a gigantic shift in the economy of EV's, and ICE's would be obsolete overnight. Graphene is the holy grail. Without affordable graphene batteries, "going green" on a really huge scale is economically unfeasible (and not all that green really), unless you just want to have less industry and let poor people starve. Until graphene, it's "nice" to make "some" EV's so that the rest of the technology is refined and ready to go.

I live in Illinois, so if I had an EV, even a graphene EV, I'd mainly be trading carbon emissions for nuclear waste. Tomatoes -tomahtoes. And as you mention in West Virgina, an EV would be long dead before you ever recouped the emissions put into making the battery. West virginians can save the planet by avoiding EV's, given their grid power. Arguably that's the fault of the state's approach to the power grid, but it's still true. If you want to play captain planet, then pressuring West Virginaian politicians to explore power generation options would be a much better use of one's time than buying an EV.

Currently the most ecologically friendly thing a person can do with their driving, is just drive safely. If you buy an EV (even in Idaho, powered by hydro-electric), and then you text while driving through a red light, you've just done more ecological harm than if you bought the most gas-guzzling car available. A totaled car = thousands of tons of manufacturing emissions up in smoke, so to speak. Less than half of our cars die peacefully in their beds of old age.

@Stephen Doherty You overlook that the per mile fuel cost of a Tesla Model 3 when fueled at a Tesla-branded refueling facility at the announced price of 26 cents per kWh  closely approaches or exceeds the per mile fuel cost of my fifteen year old VW diesel.

The best case scenario in favor of a Model 3 is if I refuel at home from the 120 volt / 15 amp outlet on my front porch using an extension cord to reach the curb.  My electricity cost ranges from about 6.5 cents to 8.5 cents per kWh depending upon the season of the year.  On average, the per mile fuel cost savings would be 5 cents per mile.  Each $10,000 of excess acquisition cost requires 200,000 miles of use to be amortized on fuel cost savings.  I expect lower maintenance costs, if any, to accrue to me and to not be dissipated by an excess acquisition cost.

Fully refueling a Tesla takes more than two days from my 120 volt / 15 amp drip feed.  The city will not permit me to install a 240 volt / 50 amp outlet at the curb.

A 2019 Hyundai Ioniq Blue hybrid consumes less fuel, and less costly fuel, than my VW diesel at an MSRP of $22,400 less a $1,000 incentive.  The payback time to purchase a Tesla Model 3 is extended when compared to purchase of a new Hyundai instead of comparing to my well-used VW.

Both can be refueled at a rate in excess of 100 times that of a Tesla-branded refueling pump at 120 kilowatts and do so without causing incremental and cumulative damage to the fuel tank.

I'm not in favor of driving a 4,500 pound land yacht with a 1,200 pound fuel tank.  I drove a car which weighed only 400 pounds more than a Tesla fuel tank in the 1970s.  (a 1964 Simca 1000, curb weight 1,600 pounds with a full tank of gasoline)

text: Now, the fun part starts when you compare the amount of electricity out of your wall socket to what was actually produced at the power plant. Transport of electricity is not without cost. Sometimes only 15% of the energy produced reaches your wall socket. Electricity grids are truly wasteful. Then, on top of that, another conversion takes place when you "fill up" your electric car. That transformation process has an efficiency of 80%. You'd actually end up with only 12% of the energy produced. So, comparing these numbers with the gasoline case makes it very debatable if electric cars are better for the environment. In many cases, they are worse. We'll cut the electric vehicles some slack though. Let us assume 25% overall efficiency for the process of "filling up" our 30 kwh car. It would then require 4 times as much energy generated as stated, bringing it up to 8.08 T annual CO2 production (using the video's numbers). This would make it about 36% worse than a gasoline car. And ... another thing .... really? A 30kwh battery, that would be 30 kw for one hour? That would be a 40 HP car, like we had in 1908? And you could drive that for a whole hour before the battery was drained? Who would want a car like that? We'll just call it the roadrunner .. meep meep!

Awesome vid. And not a surprising result üòÇ Couple of thoughts tho:
1) As it seems to take, on average, 1 - 2 years to offset a mid sized electric car, if you're the sort of person to buy a new car every couple years to escape the worst of resale, then you're not doing any favours for the environment. It seems you have to keep a new electric car for several years to make any significant difference to co2 emissions.

2) Seeing as selling your old gasoline car and buying a new electric car will take approx. 5 years to break even regarding co2 emissions, again unless you plan to keep that electric car for years more past the "break even" point, you've done no favors to the environment. So buying a new electric car instead of keeping your gasoline car is a useless effort in terms of co2, as you'd have to keep that electric car for closer to a decade for mother nature to notice you.

Remember, there's no point just breaking even, you've got to keep the electric car for a couple more years past break even point, otherwise you've barely made dent to your co2 emissions. But then every little bit does help.

So if you're not the sort of person to keep a new car for 6+ years, then it's only worth buying an electric car if you had to buy a new car anyway.

text: These are all fantastic arguments, presented in a refreshingly cogent and thorough manner. There's one point you missed though, and that's the issue of WHERE the emissions are released and the challenges that answer presents. When it comes to congested cities, it behooves everyone to minimize tailpipe emissions distributed throughout the city to a centralized location -- a powerplant's smoke stack. The emissions issue isn't limited to GHGs like CO2, as ICE  vehicles produce numerous other harmful compounds. Centralizing those GHG and toxic chemical emissions to powerplants makes the job of regulators much easier, and dramatically improves air quality in a densely populated city. IMHO, ceteris paribus, this one benefit is enough to justify making the switch away from ICE vehicles.

text:
The obvious message here could have been that the emission performance in the production and operation of ICE and Electric vehicles can be substantially improved when and if we get leadership and the financial commitment to further improve the national energy mix. In other words, by investing in renewable energy at a rate at least a fraction of what China is doing right now - much to the benefit of its economy and its environment.

I would note that production estimates are probably flawed anyway, so it may make more sense to focus on emissions while driving until better information can be had. Tesla, for example, claimed recently that by 2019, its Gigafactory will be Solar powered (probably backed by its own batteries). If that is true, than production of its cars will not contribute to CO2 emissions - only the production of whatever components it does not manufacture (assuming they come from 'dirty' factories) that it purchases and adds to inventory would count. And since it is producing its own battery packs, I suppose it makes a huge difference, and actually makes your 100 kWh battery pack example flawed or wrong. That would be good news, as it would mean the "emission payback" occurs much sooner than we thought.

text:
This is a great video, but contains a few flaws:

1. An individual considering between an ICU and an EV wouldn't buy an "average US emissions vehicle", but rather (for the 30KwH battery comparison) a similarly sized small commuter vehicle with much lower emissions. This since the "average US emissions" includes big gas guzzling pick-up trucks and similar vehicles, along with older less efficient ICU's in the vehicle fleet.
2. Emissions to produce and transport gasoline, roughly 1 gallon wasted per 4 gallons of fuel produced.
3. The type of traffic the vehicles operate in. EV's are a LOT more efficient in start/stop traffic, while ICU's give comparatively less emissions on long-haul trips.
4. The consideration of buying a used commuter vehicle rather than a new vehicle.
5. Comparison between hybrids against EV's would be interesting, and different types of EV's against each other.

Also, a cost comparison would be nice, along with "Time to regain lost money"

It‚Äôs also worth mentioning that e.g. Tesla uses only renewable electricity to run their factories which affects this a lot, but that may or may not be the case with other manufacturers. So all in all, the EV production emissions, at least in case of some manufacturers, are likely to be much lower than the concervative numbers used here.

text:
1. The lifetime of the batteries is strictly connected to the usage ratio - the more you are going to use your car, the faster you will need to replace your batteries and as far as I know, new batteries for Toyota Prius cost 5500$.
2. The second disadvantage of batteries is their dependence on temperature. The only temperature independence batteries are VERY expensive (almost 3 times more expensive than those in Tesla) and production process is so complicated there is no possibility to mass produce them.
3. In your calculations, you forget to mention that electricity is not cheap. Production of electricity is expensive and transmission have very high losses. If everyone changes their gas cars to electric cars, in USA energy demand will increase up for >40%. Good luck California ;)

So if you take under consideration only car/battery production, how much CO2 is released to the atmosphere during gas car usage and you don't consider everything besides which has to be updated/changed/implemented - this has no sense.

Ok, let we get this straight. You producing an electric car. Jeeeej! And now you need to produce electric energy to fuel it. How do you do it? Hmm... SOLAR SYSTEM! Jeeeej! Free energy from the sun! Ok. So now you have to develop solar panels. Solar panels are creating electricity but... DC. So you need to... buy batteries! Why? Because converting DC to AC takes power and effort, you can't just compensate this with capacitors because if there will be a huge drain jump - you can destroy the entire system - why? IGBT drivers are VERY delicate and diodes can not only be broken with too high voltage - but also with too small voltage (there is no better DC-AC converter than IGBT). Ok, so now we have AC, what next? Now we have to transmit this electricity. How far? 50 miles - no problem. 100 miles? Shiet. You need to create a transformer to make a higher voltage to reduce losses and give ~200V AC at the output... 200V? Shiet, this means you need a second transformer, which will lower the too high voltage and stabilize it. What else do you need? Hmmm... At least 400 miles of cable (L1, L2, L3, N).

How much CO2 will take to produce a transformer? How much it will take to produce this cables? How much it will take to produce additional batteries and solar panels? The problem with electricity is physic - at this moment we just can't make it in an efficient way, that's why it is expensive.

The true fact is that the CO2 we will save when we resign from using gas engines will be spent on everything else with is required to develop electricity and maintain it. Besides, how much percentage of a CO2 production is made by vehicles? Hmm... 10%? Less?

You need to understand - electric cars is a totally new market (car market, electricity market, transmission market) and they will do and say anything to make new customers ;) People, normal people are customers. If cars are responsible for less than 10% CO2 production, why they don't lower CO2 production for what is responsible the 90% rest of "something"? There is an answer - because taking down this 90% will decrease some markets and smaller market = less money.

text:
Nice video, but if this is correct you really should offer further explanation because this claim contradicts basic physics, and in the end even if true it is misleading. 

Every time energy is transferred  / converted (into the battery and out of the battery) you loose energy. So if the energy in electric cars came from burning gasoline to charge the batteries it would always be the case the that electric cars are worse for the environment. (In this video your environmental criteria are solely based on CO2 emissions, and that is another concern.)

On the other hand if the energy in the battery comes from energy sources that produce less CO2 than burning gasoline, the door opens for your claim to be correct. US electrical energy comes from (roughly) 30% coal, 30% natural gas, and 20% nuclear and 20 renewable.  Coal emits about twice as much CO2 as natural gas, but the two averaged together emit about the same amount as burning gasoline (per unit energy created). And we also have to consider electric cars loose about 20% of the energy used to charge the battery. So if it is true that using electric cars puts less CO2 in the air than using gasoline cars,  -it is because our nation is using natural gas, nuclear, and renewable to generate 70% if the nations electricity, and burning gasoline emits more CO2 than those energy sources. In short the electric car creates less emissions  from usage because electricity (on average and currently) comes from cleaner fuels (in terms only of CO2 emissions) than gas, and that  difference outweighs the losses associated with having to store energy in the batteries. 

That leads to a less superficial understanding of this topic.  If the US ever starts using more coal (which is the one fuel America has a lot of still) this claim about electric cars will not be true. Also one ought to think about the how the 30% we get from natural gas has only happened in the last 20 years as the direct result of fracking technology, which introduces other environmental concerns. Also nuclear power is not free of environmental risks. 

It should be clear that using a 3000lb electric car to move 1 person around is not significantly better for the environment than using a gasoline car. If we are serious about surviving ourselves we need to use less energy -in the context of transportation that means embracing efficient forms of mass transit, and we need to invest more heavily in renewable energy.

text:
@william anderson Lots of people parrot that argument without actually understanding it. ;)  They probably watched the episode of Mythbusters where they tested it (But weighted their categories in an arbitrary fashion)
Most motorcycles are definitely better from a carbon emissions standpoint,  That's pretty much directly equivalent to having better fuel economy.
They can often be worse from a pollution perspective, since they often don't have catalytic converters or other pollution controls.  They'll often produce more nitrogen oxides, unburned hydrocarbons, and carbon monoxide.  You're trading better economy and less carbon for a higher proportion of smog.
To say that they're "worse for the environment" would require a much more in-depth analysis.  I expect it's likely better overall, even if it's worse in some ways.

Also, don't forget that car's aren't the only EVs available.
Electric bicycles and motorcycles have much better energy economy.  A 1kWh battery (1/30th the size of the leaf) on a bicycle will give more than enough range for most commutes.  The main limiter there is actually travel time.  Most people won't want to ride more than 40 minutes or so, which limits you to around 15-20km.  You could do 20km each way, and get home with around a "half tank" remaining. 
A motorcycle would end up somewhere in between, on both battery size, and economy.

text:
@Jared Bennett Right.  A lot of people do dismiss bikes as an answer because they don't work for everyone, but they are great for the people who do live within around 10 miles from work (which is a significant number of people, even if the average is further).  For those that need to go further, I think ideally new types of vehicle need to be created that isn't 20:1 vehicle:payload ratio.  It's certainly possible, though people need to accept that they're going to be different than their existing cars.  You can't expect everything to be exactly the same, but skip the bad stuff.
A big part of the reason society has the problems we do now with vehicle carbon emissions is that the status quo was created when nobody cared, and now they don't want to go backwards on any of the conveniences of that excess.
author: nwimpney

text:
@nwimpney On your point about bus schedules, private companies put a lot of effort into balancing cost effectiveness with public convenience, thus they have more buses running during their rush hours (normally every 10-20 minutes or so) and fewer between the rush hours ( maybe around 1 bus every 40 minutes to an hour and a half).  "True efficiency" would not come from /everyone/ using individual small transport; you can think of it like adding up the parasitic losses of each vehicle and divided by the number of people, versus the parasitic losses of one large vehicle divided by the number of people.

Contrary to that, Van pool, bus, etc... isn't practical for everyone, for an endless number of reasons; cargo, route/destination, availability, medical reasons, etc... So really it would require an ever-changing balance of the two.

text: Most electric generating plants in the USA use coal.   Coal has to be mined, processed, and transported.   Coal generating plants also have extensive anti-pollution systems for example crushing limestone into powder to blow into the flue gases to react with remaining hydrocarbons so they can be filtered out.  The limestone also has to be mined and transported.  Transmission of electricity has losses, the wires are heating the air and it requires more production to get the energy from the plant to the outlet.   The Federal Government considers that it takes around 10,000 to 10,800 Btus of fuel to produce one kilowatt hour of electricity delivered to the customer (a kilowatt hour is about 3,400 Btus).  That makes an Electric plant at best about 34% efficient (while the plants themselves are about 40% efficient).   Then you have the efficiency of the electric car.  The motors are 90 to 95% efficient and the batteries similar, then while heating the cabin and defrosting the windows on a conventional car uses waste heat, it takes  battery power on an electric car.

text:
@Agathon CO2 is not a pollutant when it is regulated by the earth normally. Part of the regulation process includes solidifying and storing it in coal under earth's surface, effectively removing it from the atmospheric carbon cycle. When we mine and burn coal as well as other fossil fuels, we revert this process and are suddenly releasing previously stored CO2 into the air ("old carbon"), which messes up the natural carbon cycle. Yes, the photosynthesis requires CO2. However, it does not require all of the CO2 we are releasing, and the fact that we are cutting down trees left and right doesn't help that case. This means a bunch of excess CO2 just sits in the air. Also, CO2 is responsible for some of the warming. Other greenhouse gases and pollutants are notably more potent than CO2 (for instance, methane, or CH4). The issue is just that we release a ton of CO2 in particular so that's what's primarily messing up the atmospheric regulation (thereby making it a pollutant!). Too much of anything is poisonous. 

To put it into perspective, water vapor is a greenhouse gas (it actually comprises a majority percentage of the greenhouse gases). However, we are not releasing "old" H2O into the atmosphere because there is no stored H2O to be released. As such, the environment is able to continue self-regulating, so the extensive amount of water vapor in the atmosphere doesnt negatively impact climate.

@Gromos≈Çaw ≈ömia≈Çy Using biofuel is definitely better than fossil fuel because of the closed system, just like you say. However, it is important to keep in mind that humans cut down or burn large amounts of vegetation every day (to clear land or to use for resources other than biofuel). Biofuel is good when you're cutting vegetation to a limited extent. When you start cutting mass amounts, even the CO2 released by burning the biomass in biofuel can overburden the limited surviving vegetation. The system becomes unbalanced because there are too few carbon sinks to absorb all of the CO2 released. Biofuel largely works under the ideal assumption that you are replacing everything you cut down with new saplings/seeds and allowing enough time for sprouts to grow.
Think about it like this: if you cut down every plant in the world and then burned it all as biofuel, where would the released CO2 go? There would be no plants to photosynthesize and take in the CO2. Obviously this is an extreme example, but I hope it explains my point.

text:
@Austin 
More than once I have pointed out that one problem with solar, on Earth or other planets, is that it's dark half the time.  There are also the issues you bring up about solar intensity being less when the sun is up but not directly overhead.  But, it might be good enough.

It isn't quite right to say "there is nothing we can do about that," though.  Obviously we can't stop the Earth from spinning and even if we could there are obvious reasons not to.  But the surface of the Earth isn't everything.  In a high orbit the sun is always available, it isn't ever on the horizon, the panels can be pointed right at it, and there is no atmosphere or clouds blocking the sun's rays.  A solar panel in geosynchronous orbit will collect eight times as much energy as that same panel on the surface of the Earth.

Obviously the panels themselves can be made more efficient.  Look up "optical rectenna" for instance.  But yes, the "rotating Earth" problem is still there.  So, put it in orbit.

When talking about the varying sources of electricity, you are only talking about ONE vehicle. What would happen if every vehicle in a particular state ceased to be gasoline (or diesel) powered, and became electric instead? Plus, have any studies been done on the environmental impact of taking that amount of energy away from the water (and erosion) cycle? text:
The MIT study doesn't present sufficient evidence for statistical difference. Those error bars aren't a footnote; every point within the intervals are statistically equivalent, and a lot of those error bars in the figures overlap with each other because they're so damn big.

There's so many comparisons that the probability of Type I Error is through the roof. Assuming they used standard 0.05 critical values for the individual bars. Can't tell; it's not labelled where it should be. If those bars are calibrated for overall specificity, then that does explain why they're so big in comparison to some others and maybe there is ONE particular model or two that have lower emissions but no broad conclusion can be made.

The average is the most well-known statistic out there, but it is the least useful one. The confidence intervals are infinitely more important when drawing conclusions.

text:
Faults with electric cars:

Digging up and refining all of those resources to build the batteries.
Disposal of those batteries at the end of their useful life (current lead acid batteries are a good deal more recyclable - tho still not great).
That power has to be generated somewhere, and a whopping lot of it.  It then has to be transported to the charging location.  Fabricating those power generation facilities have their own problems, not the least of which go back to point 1.  The resources for transporting the power over vast distances are also pretty insane - and limited in the types (copper, et al) and availability of said resource.

Mean emissions would not change - unless the new power generation facilities were safe nuclear (salt), which has its own disposal issues (though less than current nuclear approaches).

In the end... there won't be much gain environmentally, and in local areas (where the power is generated) worsen considerably.  And the dumps into which all of those batteries get dumped (or recycled) will make superfund sites seem as safe as a neighborhood park.

The only real offset is the potential life span of the vehicle itself.  With fewer parts and some improved product quality they could last decades, whereas modern cars, even quality ones, tend to begin falling apart after 5; designed obsolescence to keep us consuming them.

As all of the manufacturers push into more ev production more mines will need to be opened, and they own't all be in remote areas.  Currently there are thousands of acres of evaporation ponds, it isn't just pure clean water vapor coming off those chemical and element laden waters, are those emissions accounted for in the battery production?  (or any of the mining or lithium extraction emissions or just battery production itself?)  What is the environmental impact of pumping oil out of the ground, transporting it, transporting it again, refining into gasoline, transporting that, then putting it into a vehicle vs extraction of coal, transporting, burning, etc.. of course blended with the other sources of electricity (those solar panels aren't emissions free, they had to be produced and shipped as did the controllers, inverters, wiring, mounting, etc...). text:
The focus here is too much on the production of the battery which, though important, is somewhat irrelevant. 

The real issue is that in a thermodynamic system there is energy lost to entropy at each step in the process. The way you fuel your car is essentially the same way you fuel your body. 

Now, if you were to eat say...20 pounds of corn...that would be a lot of corn. Certainly more than you could eat in one sitting. However, feed that much corn to a cow and the equivalent meat you would get to eat would be just enough for a single meal. Adding steps to the process always results in a loss of available energy within a system that can be used for energy.

In a gasoline powered car you have the shortest distance between fuel and motion, the goal of the automobile. Fuel enters the cylinder and is sparked, creating an explosion that drives your cylinder and pushes your transmission. (I'm jumping steps here but generally this is it).

In a battery powered car first the fuel must be used to charge the battery. Following the charging of the battery the "fuel" (battery) is then used in a similar way to move the car....producing energy to move the transmission to turn the driveshaft. 

You've added a step to the metabolic pathway which always results in a loss of energy due to inefficiency (entropy). This also completely ignores any possible resistances in the wiring from the energy factory to your battery.

The internal combustion engine is a marvel because the reaction happens right in front of you. It's as basic of a step process that's ever been created. If an idea was better (and cheaper) it would overtake it, period. Electric cars have only survived due to subsidies and have never stood on their own feet. It's just not cheaper.

Average distance vehicles drive - USA 22,000km, NZ 14,000, Australia 15,000, UK 14,000km - so between 38 and 60km per day.
EV's use between 10kwh and 20 kwh per 100km.

text:
Electric cars have a LONG way to go before they will be practical for mass adoption.
The serious shortcomings are:
1) Short range compared to IC engine powered vehicles
2) Very poor winter cold weather performance
3) Extremely long refueling times. These are the ultimate deal breaker for those who can't charge at home.
4) Massive increase in the load on the utility grid which in many areas is already taxed to it's limits during peak demand hours.
5) Wholly inadequate refueling network. Cross country trips are typically twice as far and take at least twice as long due to having to 
go FAR out of your way to find a charging station.

Some of these shortcomings could be overcome by taking the electricity needed to charge the batteries and using it to generate hydrogen instead. Hydrogen eliminates most of the shortcomings except #4 and #5.
Another solution could be to use natural gas powered fuel cells to generate electricity for electric cars. That would eliminate shortcoming #4.
Unfortunately, current fuel cell technology which utilizes such fuels is severely hampered by that fact that fuel cells become poisoned relatively quickly and must be frequently replaced.

The fact is, the market will always automatically adopt the most practical and efficient solution. That is currently petro fueled IC engine vehicles. The most practical and efficient solution always requires the fewest resources when you honestly look at the ENTIRE energy and resource footprint needed to produce and fuel it.

author: Marc Redgate

text:
The video appears to use figures from the EPA(the window sticker mpg numbers) as basis for calculating CO2 production.  The EPA defines MPGe as the kWh equivalent to the energy in a gallon of gasoline.  This figure does not include any of the losses involved in producing the electricity, from power plant emissions/construction emissions, to power line losses and added construction needed, charging losses, costs due to charging time(I can get $100/hr consulting), or the energy costs/material costs required to support dilute, intermittent electricity from solar and wind.  Hydropower is just as reliable and readily available and controllable as fossil fuel generation, but much more localized in production  so the costs are likely in a range similar to fossil fuels.  There is an additional cost to electric cars in the time required for charging, and the costs associated with limited range, and the fact that currently electric cars are not charged for road usage through the fuel taxes and the costs of subsidies for wind and solar.

If you have a  fairly limited commute to work, and are able to "stack" most of your other driving into single trips an electric car probably makes some sense.  You do have to be dedicated to making it work which requires more of your time.

I think for most people the most reliable, economic choice for a second, mainly commuting vehicle is a reliable hybrid  with no subsidies attached.  It provides the convenience of a gas powered car for commuting and longer trip with significantly lower operating costs than a strictly gas powered car.

text:
You did a really good research, thank you for valuable information. But, I agree in everything except for emissions for electricity production...
Even if you live in Idaho, your power will not come primarily from hydro.
Here's why:
While providing electricity, hydro power and other renewables are always maxed out, because they are the cheapest. That means, that there is only a fixed ammount of renewable electricity. There is no way to provide additional water or additional sun, because there is none. The only powerplants which can and do deliver additional power to the grid are thermal power stations, gas, oil or coal, as they have a lot of storage.

You can also think of it like that: With increasing number of electric cars in Idaho, the hydro power will represent less and less in total electricity mix and the average emissions will be getting higher. And even if a whole state had a surplus of hydropower, less exports to other states would cause emissions there.
Unfortunately, there's no free lunch :(

text:
" And it's not zero CO2, and never will be unless power production shifts to nuclear (wind, solar, hydro will never produce even a majority of our needs)."

Except that it will.  It is already providing that in several countries today, and more gets built every year.

"And most cobalt is in China. "  No, the largest Cobalt reserves are in the DRC, Australia is second, then we have Cuba, Philippines. Zambia, Canada, Russia, Madagascar.  China doesn't even make list.

"Want to be dependent on China, the way we have been dependent on the Middle East for the past 60 some years, and all of the problems that has caused?"  See above.

"And then there is the extra cost of building battery cars.  That means it takes more of our labors to get one.  I suppose you could calculate the CO2 for that, as well as a drag on the economy."  They are presently more expensive to buy, but far cheaper to own.  So for many people they offset the initial cost over time.

"And I've read that if 1/2 of all cars were electric, there would not be enough raw materials to make the batteries."

That claim is based on technology being static and never changing.  Here is the computer forecast from 1949: ""Where a calculator like ENIAC today is equipped with 18,000 vacuum tubes and weighs 30 tons, computers in the future may have only 1000 vacuum tubes and perhaps weigh only 1¬Ω tons."  I'm pretty sure your computer weighs far less than 1.5 tons today.

"And then there is still an open question that is much more complex than electric cars: if CO2 emissions from cars is at all significant to the environment.  If not, then this entire exercise is a waste."

No it isn't, as oil is a finite resource, and will run out one day.  So we may as well start replacing it now, before that happens.

text:
1: CO2 is plant food.
2: Sources such as hydroelectric dams are already maxed out.  Every electric car ADDS to the national electric consumption.  That means you have to look at "where is the INCREASE in electric production coming from" ... and that is NOT from non-controllable sources such as solar or wind -- it doesn't cost a power company any more to draw full-power out of a solar array than it costs to draw only half that.  Same for wind.  So... those are ALSO going to be used to the fullest capacity possible.  Which means that all EXTRA consumption is going to come from only 2 sources: Nuclear, and carbon-based fuels.  Carbon-based fuels are generally used last, because costs are roughly proportional to production levels.  Hydro-powered generators are never shut down, except to perform maintenance.  Gas-fired generators are shut down at the drop of a hat, due to nothing more than "It's 4:05 pm in the rust-belt, so a lot of factories just shut down their machinery, and now we're pumping electrons that nobody wants"

text: CO2 emissions are something of a red herring, since the "science" that CO2 will lead to catastrophic climate change is hardly settled at worst and dubious at best; there are other emissions, like water vapour, which are bigger contributors to greenhouse gasses in the atmosphere. The bigger issues with electric cars are the toxicity of the waste at end of life as well as the fact that joule for joule, a vehicle powered by, for example, diesel is more efficient than an electric vehicle when the energy measure from creation to end of life is tallied. A diesel is also more practical for longer-haul trips, especially trips away from ready sources of refuelling or recharging, especially as battery capacity declines over time, making electrics a far less reliable vehicle for anything beyond readily available charging points. Electrics are also great for places with cheap power, e.g. hydropower, as well as places where you want to keep air relatively clean, like cities, though admittedly you are pushing externalities to other places, like the countryside where you place the power generation plants.

@sebo I am not claiming the world is emission free, but most of the world wide growth is in renewable energy, and that growth will only accelerate as renewable energy gets cheaper every year.  The cost of building solar and wind keeps dropping every year and will therefore be more and more attractive, and fossil fuels will be less and less competitive.

The benefits of electric cars is that you can clean up transportation emissions by cleaning up the grid.  You can't make fossil fuel transportation cleaner once those vehicles are on the road.  They will pollute until they get scrapped.

With electric cars, unlike fossil cars, you can examine and do something about the emissions yourself.  You can buy a solar array and charge the car emission free if you choose to.  You can not make your own gasoline if you choose to.  You can buy energy from cleaner providers in areas that offer choice of utilities.  

People also neglect to examine pollution besides emissions.  Fossil cars around the world use tens of Billions of gallons of motor oil annually.  That oil usually is sold in quart containers, which means tens of Billions of empty motor oil plastic bottles end up in land fills.  Along with Billions of oil filters.  Those cars when they get old tend to leak that oil, there is a staggering amount of motor oil that leaks from cars onto public streets, which then gets washed into waterways when it rains.

And we haven't talked about all the belts, spark plugs, transmission fluid and the pollution from transporting oil around the world.  Anyone that has seen how the Canadian tar sands destroy and pollute pristine land would think twice about where some of the oil is coming from.  

In the end, there is no downside to eliminate oil consumption as much as possible.  It is a finite resource, that causes staggering amount of pollution, and although this can't be solved overnight, it needs to be addressed, and the time is to do so is now.

text:
Your claims are extremely strange.

"Why companies like Tesla are able to cram up so many useless or unnecessary features such as retractable door handles, a big iPad on the dash, a "jack mode" on the suspension for when you need to change a tire"

None of those are useless.  The retractable door handles help make the car aerodynamic increasing range.  The big touch screen controls the entire car, replacing obsolete buttons and switches, and allows the car to be updated with newer features as time goes on.

The Jack Mode is used on all cars with air suspension, to max out the suspension and turn off the self leveling feature.

"self-driving systems"  The self driving systems are extremely useful and will help people avoid accidents and assist in driving long distances or in traffic.

" instead of creating a system that can help the car charge itself when running"  They probably didn't waste any time on having the car charging itself while running, as that would literally violate the laws of physics and thermodynamics.  You can look up perpetual motion machines and why they don't work if you are confused.

"but what happens on long road trips?  Eventually someone is going to run out of electricity in the middle of nowhere"  That claim literally makes zero sense.  Do you take random trips in your gas car and just run out of gas in the middle of nowhere????  The car shows you the range real time, and if you put in a destination that exceeds the cars range, it will automatically route you to a charging station.  It will not have to be "forcedly tow the car somewhere to have it plugged in and get it recharged."

"I know there are also cars that charge in low time, but I find it inconvenient to have to wait 20-30 minutes for the dang car to get fully charged."

That claim also makes zero sense.  Cars today have over 300 miles of range.  That distance is at least 4+ hours of driving.  After 4 hours, people will need to use restrooms, get food, stretch and take breaks.  Charging the car during those breaks, assuming you are driving more than 300 miles, is a non issue.

So, you are claiming you frequently drive more than 500Km without stopping, just to stop for 2 minutes and drive 500Km more?

Because literally no one on the planet does that.

text:
Sort of.  But to be fair, the grid cannot 'waste' energy.  Generation must be balanced with use at all times or bad things happen.  This is one of the reasons that you often see windmills not rotating next to ones that are.  Windmills are the easiest thing for a grid operator to simply shut off when too much power is being generated.  This practice is called curtailment.  Coal and nuclear are neither easy nor cheap to turn on and off, sometimes requiring days to start back up.  Therefore operators of these plants will often choose to sell the power coming out of these plants at a loss on the open market because it's still far cheaper than shutting down.
If you can charge at night and reduce curtailment then that's great for the environment.  If you're just using coal generated electricity, then your pollution footprint is the same regardless of when you're charging.

The ultimate solution is to increase grid transmission capacity and storage capacity.  This leads to better utilization of cheap and available renewable power, while forcing the expensive and polluting legacy operators out of the market.

text:
@Red Baron : Let me start by thanking you for keeping this a good discussion. 

My caveat about national security covers, in my opinion, most of what you list here. Of course, practically anything can be argued to fall under the ubrella of national security, including the buying habits of consumers, so at this point we're reduced to our personal opinions on the matter.

In reality economies and the emergence of technology are very complex. Another person could jump in and say that the only thing that matters is advertizing and messaging/media, since that is the well from where all political will and economic activity springs. Another could say that women's rights and status in society is the primary driver of population, and the distribution thereof, therefore shaping the economic, environmental and political landscapes. 

The perspectives are endless. It's interesting to look through any number of perspectives, but the lens that I usually settle on sees people behaving in their own interests, and always looking for a way for their surroundings to improve. This places a natural demand on producers to constantly refine and innovate. Looking back, it doesn't take much imagination to see how a person would prefer a gas or electric furnace over an open fire pit, or how the internal combustion engine is preferable to an external combustion engine. Reduced consumption, safety, health concerns, and convenience are all tied together in a nice package, so it just makes sense. 

Same with an electric car. Why would I buy a loud, heavy, maintenance intensive, smelly chunk of 150 year-old technology when I could get something that is (insert antonyms here). And yes, just plain environmental concerns factor into this, because people do (to one degree or another) see their surroundings as a vital interest. Some people include far away places in this calculation, while others don't even wash their hands, but very few people want more pollution just for the sake of it. 

But, to address your point a bit: The government is in fact an invention of popular demand, and seeks to manifest the will of the general population as a matter of principle. It is highly effective when it comes to some endeavors, particularly when the mandate is well defined (Manhattan Project), and where huge strategic gains accrue (GPS, cryptology, etc.). Improvements in electric vehicles is a long game, however, and the collapse of western civilization is not imminent. I see plenty of smart people with plenty of money in the private sector racing for the next best electric car. I can see maybe a few federal education grants in support of the cause, but there are other priorities for federal dollars right now.

author: Simon Ploumas

text:
Vehicle batteries tend to lose capacity in the first couple of years, but data so far indicates that most only lose about 15% even after 100,000 miles. For most users that's similar to the loss of bhp for ICE engines, and wouldn't require the batteries to be replaced. But prior to recycling, there is another option. 

Repurposing. A vehicle battery pack that's only holding 70% of its original design could arguably need replacing. But, at the right price, could happily be used for static electricity storage, where volume and weight are not constraints.

Such repurposed batteries may have another 10 years of useful life before needing to be recycled. Maybe more, maybe less, the industry is just too young to give definitive data at this time.

text:
Thanks for the video. Very educational!

Other things not covered is that lithium and other elements used in the batts can be recovered and re-cycled easily. I read somewhere that 99% of the materials used for actual power generation can be recovered. The re-cycling is not any different from recycling lead and other stuff from standard batteries, except with lithium batteries, it will be less messy. Though we will be harvesting lithium for the next 50 years or so, it is good to know that we can recycle the batts and build fresh ones thus needing less of farming lithium in the future. Most likely, it will also be cheaper. 

2nd - as of this time, ICE is being used to "farm" these minerals. In the near future, they too will be electric, thus reducing emissions further. Same for almost all value chain or machinery used for production. 

3rd - The impact on maintenance in adding to emissions or carbon can accumulate through time and can be added to the equation. Disposing, recycling of oils, etc also adds to pollution. With electric, there is no need for voluminous oil changes, the use of filters, belts, cogs, gears, etc., etc. Probably the oil differential is the oil, and maybe some grease for the axle or joints, and some lubrication for some parts. And maybe only air filter is necessary for changes. This does not just lower cost of maintenance, but it also lower the carbon footprint of the vehicle. 

4th - electric vehicles is and will usually be attached to solar or wind power generation, maybe more so with solar. In the long run, as battery price goes down, and solar panels become cheaper, these vehicles will be charged by the car owners themselves. 

5th - Expect to see new battery tech or breakthroughs where we will see solid state batteries that can be charged in just 10-15 min vs 30-60 min. They will be higher density or capacity, requiring less volume, materials for the same capacity. They will also last longer as they will last longer (5,000-10,000+) charge cycles thus having no more need to change batteries in fact even past 8 years. Also, the weakness of current batt tech his the electrolyte. They break down eventually. If they go solid or some other tech, there is no need for this limitation and most likely recycling will be easier, faster, and cheaper. 

As we are still new and the revolution is ongoing, expect to see how electric vehicles will still move to a lower carbon footprint as other value chain and tech innovations eliminates those present negatives.

Also there is a problem that where it is always windy, and always sunny, do not necessarily correlate where the people live.  Thus you have to run more electric transmission lines. text:
So at the end of the day, it's 6 or one half dozen of the other as far as emissions go, now lets look at other considerations such as fuel costs, availability, repairs, etc...

There is no problem with finding a gas station where you can fill up and go on your way, and the average time to do that with a gas engine vehicle is between 10 and 20 minutes where the EV counterparts have a limited range of travel, down time for recharging the EV, and a limited areas to recharge the vehicle. 

The commuter that has to drive more than 40 miles to work one way would be out of luck unless he or she can recharge the vehicle at work, and then there's the monetary burden of recharging the vehicle at the place of employment that is placed on the employer (if they allow for a recharge and have the right receptacle for the EV plug, and the vehicle would need to be recharged for longer than the 8 hours average that an employee puts in. (Then there's no leaving for a lunch break as that interrupts the charge, and adds more time to the recharge time too.) These are all considerations as well just on the ability to get around without your vehicle becoming a ball and chain tethered to you.

Now for the repairs. Most modern gas vehicles are reliable for the most part, and offer good service for most of the life of the vehicle (providing the maintenance is kept up) before the vehicle needs any major repairs such as any drive train components such as an engine, transmission, or rear axle (rear wheel drive) replacements. 

The EV on the other hand, has the electric motor, the battery pack, and the electronics which are far more expensive than the gas engine electronics in the event of a failure which would offset the cost of a new or used engine or transmission in a gas engine. This doesn't include the fact that very few places are available where a technician would be qualified to repair the EV, forcing the owner of the EV to pay a premium rate to repair it.

I like EV technology, as it's certainly came a long ways, but it's still got a long way to go until it's practical for anything but some "feel good" vehicle for some virtue signaling snowflake who lives only a couple of miles from college, and recharges their vehicle on mom's dime while they play video games in her basement.

text: Good informative video, but CO2 isn't the only thing affecting the environment... only 80% of a car can be recycled; mainly the metal parts; while plastic, rubber, fabrics, composites, electronics, wiring, ceramics, are often incinerated, put in landfill or shipped off to poor countries that don't have recycling infrastructure.  During the lifetime of the car the microscopic tyre and brake pad fragments that are worn away get blown into the air or washed by rain into the water supply, which affects all life.  The other fumes and compounds given off by cars, which contain sulphur oxides, nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, carbon (soot),  hydrocarbon vapour, are arguably more harmful than the CO2 to animals and humans.  Reprocessing the metals requires lots of chemicals that are harmful and often flushed into the river.  Toxic metals such as hexavalent chromium, cadmium and lead from industrial waste is being absorbed by microbes, fish, farm animals, crops and ending up in our food, water and air.  Plastic pollution has been all over the news in the UK since the Blue Planet 2 documentary.  CO2 emission is bad, but we often overlook the other pollutants.

text:
A few things you did not consider....  1) Lithium mining is often considered bad for the environment because of where it is mined.  Countries such as Chile have few if any environmental regulations and standards.  The same can be said about the copper, nickel and pretty much any other hard rock mining.  Things to look at would be acid mine drainage , leachates, and tails ponds common in hard rock and most other mining operations.  Does the host country remediate and clean up after mine closers or leave the mess behind.  Also any mining tends to be a very carbon intensive process requiring large equipment that tends to run on diesel.  2) of lesser concern is the end of life battery.  In NA at least we are getting better about battery recycling, but in much of the world batteries end up in the land fill.  The acid and heavy metals in batteries can be very damaging to the environment especially in poorly designed land fills.  

For myself I live in a cold climate where we can have problems with our batteries on regular vehicles.  Electric vehicles are completely impractical because of the miles you get to a charge, the fact that any battery does much more poorly in extreme temperatures, the risk of being stranded, the time to recharge, etc.... I also find the cost of purchasing an EV prohibitive.   I will personally not be moving to an electric vehicle.

text:
@Lorenzo Bolla de Oliveira In my opinion, the only problem with E85, is that cars that can run it are forced to also be able to run on lower octane gasoline.  This is why you always run into the problem of making a little more horsepower and see a huge drop in mileage.  

The higher octane of Ethanol based fuels needs high compression engines to take advantage of.  Not the 10:1 or 11:1 compression of engines today, but like 13.5:1 or 14:1 or higher yet.  The increase in compression yields more horsepower and torque for a given amount of air and the higher octane of Ethanol based fuels can run at those compression ratios without fear of premature detonation of the fuel.  Because E85 engines have to run on 87 octane gasoline, we cannot run those high compression numbers and thus E85 is significantly less fuel efficient.

text:
@Red Baron Yes, we are going to play semantics :). Jk. But seriously, the term "renewable energy" is very misleading as it hints that it is a free energy source. Energy ALWAYS degrades, according to the second law of thermodynamics. There is nothing renewable about wind, or solar, or hydro. And yes, these all require fuel: the same fuel that put energy-laden hydrocarbons in the ground - the sun. There is not an unlimited amount of hydro, wind, or direct solar energy. There is a set amount of insolation the earth receives and I doubt any serious studies have been done on the repercussions of robbing the earth of its incoming energy. Or for that matter, what the repercussions are for knocking down wind speeds (which are environmentally important) to generate electricity, or taking energy and erosion power out of flowing water. 

No energy is free or unlimited, is basically my point.
