text:
John McWhirter there are probably "no serious studies" because there isn't a significant effect. As you surely know, energy is neither created nor destroyed, but merely changed from one form to another. Incoming solar radiation that we "rob" with solar panels would have wound up as low grade heat dispersed in the environment and gradually leaked out into space if we didn't take it. Actually, the same thing happens when we do take it; converting solar energy to electric energy. We use the electric energy and it ultimately arrives as low grade heat dispersed in the environment. No amount of energy was lost at all, we just borrowed it for awhile.
Of course, this doesn't take into account environmental degradation due to mining and processing ores, manufacturing, transportation, etc. to get the solar panels and batteries, etc. online. Looking at the other renewables come up with similar results, no loss of energy in the system, but some, and sometimes considerable, environmental degradation.
However, compared to the cost of the alternative fossil fuels, both direct costs and external costs, and which are not renewable on a human time scale, the so-called renewable energy sources are far better in many applications.
I think you misunderstand or misunderstood the notion of renewable resources. It is that the resource can be tapped in an ongoing way without depleting the supply. This says nothing about the demand side of the equation. For example you can cut trees from a forested 100 acre plot, plant tree seedlings,  let them grow for 80 years or so, cut them out again and repeat the process over and over again. In this case, we get to use the wood produced from that plot over and over again. This does not mean there in an unlimited supply of trees. Likewise, the sun is considered a renewable resource because it is going to keep sending our planet roughly the same amount of energy each year for the foreseeable future, and millions of years beyond that.
I think you're generally on the right track, I just wanted to help clarify a bit. Hope it helped.

author: Red Baron

text:
@John M "There is not an unlimited amount of hydro, wind, or direct solar energy."

When we are talking about a solar time frame of millions of years, the relevance of it being infinite or not is not really relevant to anything.  It is unlimited as far the human race will be gone for millions of years before the sun starts having any issues.

"There is a set amount of insolation the earth receives and I doubt any serious studies have been done on the repercussions of robbing the earth of its incoming energy. "

There is no "robbing" of any kind.  Solar power simply converts light into electricity.  The effect of wind power has not been shown to have any adverse affects on anything.  We do however know the effects of continuing to use carbon energy, so whatever trade offs would be theoretically possible would pale compare to the effects to continue as we do now.

"or taking energy and erosion power out of flowing water. "

There is no specific benefit of erosion.  Hydro power can affect fish in the areas where they use freshwater.  In areas like Iceland where they use glacial run off for hydro power, the effects are literally none. 

So, while there are always some trade offs, renewable energy is the choice with the least amount of environmental harm available as of today.

text:
I have 180,000km on my 2015 i3 and it's still well over 90% capacity. Standard EV powertrain warranties these days are 8 years/160,000km, you can usually expect 10-20 year lifespan from a pack even at high mileages (70% capacity is usually considered end of life, the 10 year estimate primarily applying to packs without temperature control), after which the pack still has a resale value and a second life in grid storage. Or you can just leave it in the car if you are only doing short journeys (which most 20 year old car would only be doing).
Basically for a typical owner the battery is going to stay in until the car hits the scrapyard....which due to the higher mechanical reliability is also probably going to be later than a combustion car.
It's also worth pointing out that as battery capacities increase the number of cycles the cells in the pack go through (the primary contributor to capacity loss) for a given mileage also drops. My 180,000km on my 2015  22kWh i3 battery has taken ~1300 cycles, the same mileage driven the same way (I drive my vehicles hard) in a 44kWh 2018 i3 would only result in 650 cycles.

text:
@„ÉÅ„Çß„Ç∑„É£Áå´ Usually a modern EV BMS is pretty conservative, discouraging low state of charge both by actively preventing discharge below a limit (preventing the drive motor from running) and by more passive measures like motor power limits at low discharge. Also manufacturers have other measures of discouraging low states of charge like deliberately alarming displayed range/SoC (my Leafs for example stop displaying SoC and range at 5% reported (just over 7% actual) SoC) and my i3 warns about leaving the vehicle unattended at low SoC any time the power is switched off while SoC is 10% or below.
In practice for most EV drivers the big threats to pack longevity (in order of impact) are high temperature events caused by either operating environment or DC rapid charging (something pretty much solved on most EVs by liquid/gas active thermal management of the pack), pack design/chemistry flaws (like the LMO pack of the 2010-2013 Leaf, with stacked cells and no active cooling), cycle count, being left at high state of charge for long periods and calendar age.

Below 5% actual SoC every EV would have either turned the motor off or be in "turtle" mode (basically a limited power mode designed to allow you to limp the vehicle to a safe position off the road). Letting the pack that low is pretty rare,  many EV drivers would never have experienced it at all. In close to 300,000km of EV driving I've only hit turtle mode on an EV twice, one time was deliberate (I was seeing how the vehicle reacted to a low state of charge circling a charger) and once was within 100 meters of the DC rapid charger that was my destination.
Also a lot of the pack and cell design is fairly conservative, one of the reasons Nissan picked LMO for the Leaf was the stability of that chemistry. At this point with nearly 3 million mass produced EVs on the roads globally we have good figures on the fire stats and the rate of EV fires is a fraction of comparable combustion vehicle fires. That's given a bit of confidence to cell manufacturers to push the energy density a bit further.

text:
So, just out of interest, I plugged in the numbers from my car/driving style and found some interesting results.
The numbers are: CO2 emissions are 118g/km (compared to approx. 270g/km for the average mentioned in the video) and distance 15000km. To give the benefit of the doubt to the electric car (for a change) I reduced the yearly emissions to just 1 metric tonne per year (i.e. half of the original value). For these values, the time till ICE and EV are even is 6.5 years in total Co2 emissions. This is considering the small EV. For the extra powerful EV the time is 19.5 years! That is a long time. And what if I drove just 10 thousands kilometers a year? The time will rise to 27.8 years for the small EV and 83.3 years for the large EV! That is a really long time waiting for the return with several replacements of the battery and maybe even rewind of the electric motor (and complete car replacement for the large EV).
But let's be as generous to the electric cars as EE was to ICE. Let's explore the other extremes. Start with 20 and 30 thousand kilometers per year. That would result in 3.7 (20k) and almost 2 (30k) years for the small EV and 11 (20k) and 5.9 (30k) years for the large EV. This seems more reasonable. Oh wait, I forgot to factor in the fact that the EV is now doing greater distance, so back to 2 tonnes of C02 per year. Now we get 13.9, 3.2, 41.7, 9.7 years for the respective conditions. This does not look good, so let's go full "EV preference mode" and make the EV produce only 15% more emissions during production (the lowest estimate mentioned in the video). So:
Smallest EV 10k (1 tonne/yr): 8.3 years
Smallest EV 15k (1 tonne/yr):  1.9 years
Smallest EV 20k (2 tonnes/yr): 4.2 years
Smallest EV 30k (2 tonnes/yr): 0.97

Couple of notes, before conclusion: I might have made some errors and I sort of randomly rounded the values to single decimal digit. For that I really do apologize. If there are some errors, please correct me and I will edit that. Overall, this is a lazy comparison. The more proper way would be to factor in alternative running costs (oil, filter,...) and have a linear emissions for the EV (i.e. not 1 OR 2 tonnes) and larger yearly emissions for the large EV. This is just a quick calculation to give a general idea of the situation. Please, take the numbers as very rough ballpark estimates.

So, the conclusion. It is not that EVs are bad and my intention was not to in any way invalidate the numbers presented by EE. I just felt like there is a part of the picture missing. The missing part is that it's not black and white situation (nothing in real life is) whether EVs are more ecological than ICEs. It really depends on what you drive and how much you drive. If you commute daily, then you are gonna see faster return if you switch to EV. And therefore it makes sense to switch to EV. But it is really important to also say that if you are only using your car occasionally and it is a rather frugal ICE car then switching to EV will hurt the environment more.
It is also important to keep the facts straight and to give the whole picture to keep the research, the manufacturers, and the energy industry awake. If we say that EVs are good as they are and it is not the complete truth, they might get content with that and slow down the progress (it costs hyper massive amounts of money, so everyone will be really glad to slow down). We need to keep pointing at the shortcomings of EVs not as an excuse to drive ICE with a massive inefficient engine but to make the EVs even more ecological.

Also, think about how fast would both the ICE and EV boats sink if we considered commuting by bicycle/e-bike...

text:
This is what I like about the Internet. You post a comment and than you can watch how the minds of humans work for free.
Anyway, I never used the word pollution, just emission. And it is not me, who is concerned with CO2. This was just a supplementary material to the video that was concerned with CO2 emissions. Obviously, you can go much deeper and concern yourself with more stuff, like NOx, PM, disruption of the landscape, etc. I would like to have the time to go through all that calculations. Unfortunately, I am not a full time YouTuber, so I have to do an actual work which leaves me less time to go through all those calculations. Maybe in the future. But regardless of that, even if someone did all that, it would still give just a very broad picture. In the real world, it is simply impossible to account for everything and to be really thorough, you should do it on an individual basis.
That was one of my points. The video was about the question: "Should we make USA electric?" (the answer, concluded in the video based on some solid evidence, was yes). I wanted to point out that while this is true on the large scale, on individual scale (and in other countries), you should be more cautious and do some personalized calculations before you make a decision.

To simplify, if you drive a large 20yr old pickup truck with a 4liter V8 and you spent 95% of the time driving to work, doing 20k kilometers a year, then it makes absolute sense to switch to EV. If you drive a small economical modern car with lot of tech to make it less harmful to the environment and you drive only occasionally then switching to EV (right away) will cause more harm then keeping the ICE car. But these were just the extremes and it is a little bit more complex for anything in between.

For that reason, it is sort of dangerous to just use the average values. If you are asking whether the overall trend should be more electric cars, then it will give you some roughly correct idea (just keep in mind that you want to use median, not mean, otherwise the values will be offset by some 30+yr old trucks that convert 99% of fuel into pollution and only 1% to actual movement). But it won't give you correct answer of the complete picture.

I hope you all can understand what I am trying to say. I don't think it is that complex but maybe I am not explaining myself clearly enough. I am not trying to argue for electric cars. Mostly, because there is nothing to argue about. They are simply the future and personal preference does not matter (but if anyone is interested, I really like ICE cars, especially small European hot hatches; they are awesome and I am slightly sad that they are not in our future). The questions is, what is the current state (i.e. how soon will the "future" come) and should we try to switch to them as fast as possible? That is quite complex to answer and my point was to show that it is not that simple.

Back to the CO2 as a "pollutant". That is also a difficult topic. Basically, some of the things that come out of the car are not 100% bad, like CO2, NO2, H2O. That is why the name emissions is preferred. However, they become a problem when they are emitted in large quantities into the environment. If you don't think CO2 is a problem, try breathing in 100% CO2 gas for a few minutes. And that is before we get to the greenhouse effect, which is implicitly defined as a main point when mentioning CO2 emissions.
That's also the reason why breathing or having a furry companion in your house is not viewed as a major contributor to climate change. It is not about the chemical compound itself, it is about the quantity. That is also why we can have a debate whether to switch to EV or keep your ICE car. Both cause emission of CO2 (and yes, also other stuff) but the variable is the quantity in both cases.

Lastly, the topic of e-bikes...argh.
I really "like" how when someone mentions a bicycle, everyone start mentioning their grandma, people with disabilities and epic journeys to the arctic as an excuse not to ride ~5km to their work everyday in a moderate climate. Major part of the commuting people are able-bodied adults within the 20-45yr range. And it is no problem to ride during rain or snow - my 60+yr old mother rides everyday to work almost the whole year whether it rains or snows; and so does for example a major part of Scandinavia, so this excuse is completely invalid. You just have to work for it a little bit (like have knobby tires and a proper jacket). Yes, it is not as simple as lugging around a massive, unnecessary lump of metal. If people would be considerate enough of each other there would be no dispute and less deaths on the roads. And it is not about the "cyclists" it is about the people. An asshat on a bike will be and asshat in a car and is an asshat in real life, that's a fact. But this is actually irrelevant for this discussion (I leave it to the reader to deduce why).

text:
There are two parts to that definition posted by Dizzy peasant. The other definition is harmful effects. If we continue at the present rate of global warming we are going to be involved in sixth mass extinction of species on the planet Earth.

Now part of that is due tohuman activity related to increasing human population, such as converting forests to monoculture croplands, and the fragmenting of populations leading to reproductively isolated groups that are no longer viable, as in they die out. So this does not separate the two out, but adding increasing amounts of greenhouse gases will definitely worsen the impact of these other human activities, increasing the rate of extinction of the numbers of animals and plants already threatened by other human activities. This does not even address the number of organisms directly wiped out global warming.

Your comment about the Earth being better off with increasing numbers of plants due to increased quantities of CO2 is absurd. First, you will have much smaller land masses, so you will have fewer land species. Plus the acidifying of oceans will result in the elimination of large numbers of coral reefs, which are some of the most bio diverse and productive environments in the ocean.

An added problem that is likely, though the science is still out on that due to the complexity, is that ocean currents and air circulation between climate zones may be largely shut down, resulting in hugely narrowed temperate climate areas. That is going to be a huge problem for people. 

Coupled with the widespread disruption of modern mass production food crops while population is increasing, this will result in large-scale starvation. While that is not directly mentioned in your response, forgive me if I am biased but I would like my children and grandchildren not to have the face problems like that. For the record, starvation on that scale leads to warfare, and we have already had places where the partial collapse of farming due to drought helped trigger warfare where other issues were in place, like Syria. The problem is that in marginal regions like that, it is very hard to sort out whether the drought would have happened without global warming, or if it was part of the natural cycle in arid areas that would have happened regardless.

One would assume the utilities already optimize their electricity production cost, using the least expensive raw material plus production cost. So if one has access to natural gas and gas based electricity production, those production units will be maximized as much as practicable. The same could be said for coal states where the infrastructure and production capacity is lowest cost for coal. Both of these conditions imply that the last kW of electricity will be both expensive and likely to be more CO2 producing => fuel oil or crude oil. Now over the span of 5 years, perhaps incremental would begin to tilt more towards natural gas since that will be the lowest cost source of electricity for many years.

text: There is a huge glaring flaw making break even time only 50-30% what it should be. He figured all this with a co2 output for an average US gasoline vehicle, whereas a 2.0L turbo midsize sedan (what a sane people consider an average car, with 0-60 under 5 seconds and room for a family(Tesla size)) produces half that. A gasoline car comparable to the Nissan Leaf makes 1/3 or less co2 per mile than the "average US vehicle"  These c02 figures on comparable vehicles are even less in europe, where c02 output is further restricted. His example window sticker for co2 emissions is a 5.7 L hemi RAM fullsize truck, the least efficient passenger vehicle body and engine combo available by a huge margin and it's only 20% more than the "average co2 output" he pulls from. In my honest opinion, it's about a wash for the environment at the present. All the predictions of alternative energy power grids are woefully optimistic. The power grid is already struggling to keep up. We can't even figure out how to replace the existing power grid with green alternatives, let alone make it substantially bigger for powering cars. I don't want to say electric cars are senseless, but they are a long long way from the magic bullet people want to believe in. The benefits look like 20% reduced emissions in 20 years, if we put a decent amount into renewables. Which might not even beat the improvements on existing ICE tech. The sad truth of this is, it's really all about corporations and investment, not the environment. Oil industry might be evil, but at least we have some grasp of it, who knows what we'll be getting next. The one downside I see is that the only cost effective batteries and electronic components are pretty much coming right off the ship from China after being lightly breathed on by other nations. And people arguing lung cancer from ICE's are on pretty shaky grounds, because you don't see lung cancer of non-smokers being a giant public health problem, despite exhaust from just a couple of decades ago being hundreds of times more carcinogenic.

text: Actually, his analysis is extremely poor.  He doesn't even mention, let alone discuss the fact that ALL marginal (i.e. the next increment of X) electricity production comes from coal and hydrocarbon sources entirely.  NOBODY runs a solar cell field, or wind turbine field at anything other than the maximum level that can be squeezed out, for the simple fact that the solar cell is out there, getting shined on, regardless of whether you use the electricity or not.  50% draw from a solar panel field costs no more than 100% draw... so you ALWAYS draw the maximum possible from it at all time.  Same goes for wind turbine farms.... there is NO benefit to drawing anything less than the maximum that you can at any one time.  On the other hand, a coal or gas fired plant... you shut one of those boilers down as soon as  there is excess capacity, because if you don't have a customer to buy those electrons, then you're burning fuel and shunting those electrons into stand-by loads and NOT EARNING A CENT FOR IT.  So, despite what this guy says, ALL electricity production that is added to the baseline load is done with carbon-based fuel.  This destroys his argument that "well, in such and such state, x% comes from hydro"... yeah, but the output from the hydro plant IS ALREADY BEING CONSUMED 100% before you even plug your electric car into the wall socket.  That means the increase in production MUST come from a variable source... which a means carbon-based fuel, and nothing other than a carbon based fuel source.

text:
Joe Booth heavy metals are things like mercury or uranium, etc. Metals that are actually heavy. Lithium is literally the lightest metal that exists, being the third element on the periodic table. The only elements lighter or more common in the universe, metal or otherwise, are hydrogen and helium.

There is very little of those metals in a battery too, as he explained in the video. And what is in them is largely recyclable already today, and will become more recyclable as there are more batteries produced and used and worn down over time. These are things that are all but impossible with fossil fuels like coal or oil etc.

Furthermore, you said it yourself in your own comment that gasoline and other fossil and nonrenewable fuels are COMBUSTED and burned up. Batteries aren't combusted or consumed when you use them, they stay 100% right there in the car. Batteries are not fuel. Batteries are fuel TANKS, and electricity is the fuel.

And batteries don't die either. They lose usable capacity. But they don't lose actual capacity, they just can't make use of their full capacity after a while due to microscopic changes that occur in their internal structure due to the way they operate to charge and discharge. When you recycle them, you're essentially breaking them up into their original elements and making them into a new battery with their original structure, and thus their original capacity again. It's a bit like cleaning accumulated sludge out of your gas tank so it'll hold its full original capacity again. The gas tank isn't lost in the process, so it's never sitting around in a landfill. And even if it were, those "heavy metals" as you incorrectly call them were already in the ground to begin with, that's where we got them. But since we never burned anything up, the lithium we took out of the ground is the same lithium we'd be putting back into the ground. It isn't at all comparable to burning oil and producing greenhouse gases that were locked away in the ground but are now polluting the atmosphere after burning the oil up and fundamentally changing what it was.

text:
@Bruce Lortz An electric motor is much smaller and lighter than an equivalent power combustion engine, so there's a major weight savings there.  For example, a Tesla Model 3 is only about 10% heavier than an equivalent BMW 3 series.  The total weight penalty for an EV is much smaller than might seem.

Also, a large Lithium ion battery pack weighs about 1000 lbs, and they get more energy dense (lighter and smaller for the same energy) every year.  If solid state batteries work, then EVs may become lighter than combustion cars of similar power, size and range.

As battery costs continue to fall, it eventually costs less to build an EV than a combustion car.  For Tesla, that point happens within 2 years. For VW, maybe 5 to 7 years.  For Toyota, probably longer.  It's mostly based on battery factory economies of scale.  Tesla's Gigafactory is what enables them to build EVs for less than fossil cars within 2 years.

The trends clearly show that the future is electric.  The sooner legacy car makers figure that out the sooner they don't go bankrupt with stranded ICE assets.

text:
@Matt Lane lithium-ion batteries aren't the only battery technology in existence(as you know since you mentioned NiCad). One particular battery technology that has, in some cases, already surpassed the capacity of disposable alkaline batteries is NiMH(nickle metal hydride) and these, in fact can be used as substitutes for NiCad in most cases. Even NiCad chargers may work with NiMH batteries, but NiMH have more than double the capacity of NiCad so a 12 hour charge time could be more like 36 hours for a NiMH. This is where current ratings are important. Another point, you can use voltage regulators to ensure that whatever battery you use will not fry your circuit components. This can be implemented pretty easily, and most electronics have built-in voltage regulators anyway so it's a non-issue for the most part.

And... all batteries operate at a range of voltages. The 3.7v you mention is considered "normal" but a lithium ion battery rated at 3.7v may operate as high as 4.2v and as low as 3.0v depending it's charge and the ambient temperature.

text:
What about the environmental cost to ship the Lithium and it's batteries across the globe on freighters. This is often overlooked. Australia and South America (ie. the ‚Äúlithium triangle‚Äù of Argentina, Chile and Bolivia) provide 80 to 90 percent of lithium production. In 2016, lithium production grew by 16 percent over the previous year. Australia produced most of it, 14,300 metric tons, much of which is shipped to China for processing. Here the Lithium Ion battery cells are made, which are put back on ships and sent to wherever the cars are made, which are again shipped to the point of sale.

You also glossed over the amount of water required for the process and dismissed it as being in arid areas where nothing survives. Indigenous people in the lithium triangle worry that the high levels of water needed to produce lithium -- as much as half a million gallons per ton -- may cut into the already limited water supply in the arid and drought-ridden areas where brine sites are located. These concerns have triggered protests against the exploitation of the resources by large companies. In 2012, 33 indigenous communities took calls for consultation about lithium development to Argentina's Supreme Court.

text:
There's an error in this evaluation. You are assuming that the current percentages can be transposed to a situation where EVs are massively adopted. Doing the math on my own home country, using an average of 1.6 cars per household doing an average 15,000 miles per year, will multiply the average household usage by a factor 4 to 5. From the numbers you showed, wind and solar are hardly any factor at all (and obviously solar will never be when you want to charge the car overnight) and it will prove extremely hard to expand other green methods as most of these are in fact already used in full. Leaving nuclear, which to many-many-many-many people is no option at all.

The problem with this whole going to electric idea is that electricity is not an energy source. It is an energy transport, so it has to be produced somehow and you can't actually store it - not loss-free anyway and in Scotland they found that the most economic way to store it was to convert it to kinetic, pumping up water to a high basin and release it when the extra power is required. As such there is no point in doing a state to state comparison, because the only way to meet the additional demand from more EVs is by burning more fossil fuels. In effect, you cannot assume any better numbers than those mentioned from West-Virginia. Anything else would be daydreaming.

text:
So from the perspective of a 50-60,000km/annum EV driver who's seen plenty of traffic and bad weather (including severe snow storms where I was the only car on the road), you are way better off in an EV. A combustion vehicles fuel consumption suffers in heavy traffic while an EV's energy consumption improves (consumption scales directly with speed and whenever you are not moving the motor is off). There's also the misunderstanding about the scale of power consumption of auxiliary devices like lights & wipers vs the drive motor... a difference that often exceeds 1000 fold. Even the shortest range EVs could sit there with high beams on for weeks continuously before running the high voltage battery low.


My 2015 BMW i3 (my 3rd EV of 4) has 180,000km on the odometer, has only had one brake fluid change (and a wing mirror folding motor) as it's only maintenance (Jan 2017, as per the BMW schedule, 2nd service Jan 2019). The 2018 i3 has double that range from the same size and weight pack (44kWh). Since heating the same cabin is the same load (usually in -5C weather 0.5 kWh per hour, much less in warmer conditions) when battery capacity increases, cabin aircon/heating uses a lower proportion of the power consumption.


I've saved ‚Ç¨25,000 in running costs vs a comparable vehicle and sit in traffic every day wondering why people around me haven't switched. The only answers I've been able to reach are 1. they don't know the advantages of EV 2. they can't afford the initial price of the car (though with tax incentives a 40kWh EV is the same price as a typical car in my country) 3. a minority can't charge at home or have another niche problem (90% of the people on my commute would have a driveway to charge in).


EV drivers have generally owned combustion vehicles in the past and can directly compare from experience, very few combustion drivers have any experience whatsoever of EVs and getting over their preconceptions are the biggest hurdle. I've had people in Germany  insist to me that my irish registered car has too short range for their average 40km daily use... while I'm in the middle of road trip across europe.... having done 1,700km since I left Ireland the previous evening.....

author: John Flaherty

text:
@John Flaherty 1) The tax incentives, are not huge, they just equalise the price with similar vehicles. In my case the incentives on my i3 didn't even cover 50% of the sales and registration taxes. And for those of us in countries that import 100% of liquid fuels, produce most of our electricity from cheap renewables and have to pay tax money for CO2 emissions trading credits it's only fair that those causing less of a drain on government finances get some kind of incentive.

2) The infrastructure is pretty cheap, we have this thing called an electrical grid that goes pretty much everywhere, even in a future where all vehicles are EVs because of the impact of home charging (which covers daily use for the vast majority of owners) you actually need only a small fraction of the infrastructure combustion vehicles, largely just rapid chargers at motorway services. And that infrastructure is getting to commercial viability on it's own in countries like norway and the netherlands without any tax break or incentive.. but for low EV penetration markets someone needs to subsidise the initial infrastructure, that can be carmakers (Ionity, Tesla and Electrify America are examples of this), investors not expecting returns for an extended period (FastNed is an example of this) or government.


3) The hit to range is ~20-25% in -15C for the average EV (the average EV has a temp-controlled pack)... a combustion vehicle on average loses 15-20% of it's range in the same conditions. It's not a big issue, especially since the average EV is leaving home every single day with a full battery and we're a bit short of elves magically brimming combustion vehicle tanks in the night.

I don't know where you are getting the idea that EVs are "a more poorly performing vehicle" the reality is quite the opposite. EV torque is very useful in daily driving,  charging at home is much more convenient (and 3-12 times cheaper depending on electricity rates and fuel taxes) than the hassle of fueling a combustion vehicle, performance EVs can outperform combustion vehicles on almost every metric and there are other advantages like the ability to remotely pre-heat/cool the vehicle (very handy for quick grocery trips in winter, you can leave the car off and locked with climate running or preheat your vehicle when the movie credits roll).

I used to own an E90 M3... yet my favorite vehicle is the i3.... I'm not alone... almost all the early i3 owners in Ireland were current/former M car owners.... in fact a lot of the EV owners I know are coming from higher priced large displacement cars and SUVs.... maybe we know something you don't...

Suggestions/thoughts:
- I know that there is really not much Lithium used in batteries but given that a good chunk of it is produced in countries lacking any environmental regulations and economical/political stability, I think that we still grossly underestimate the consequences.
- There is not enough recycling capacity for batteries that can take on the future needs: we simply do not have have the scale. As a result, we have no idea if it will be more or less efficient than current processes. I guess more efficient but...
- Energy loss due to heating/cooling and adverse weather (like in Canada) is rarely fully accounted for in emission generation of electric cars. (it is low and sometimes even negligible in most ice cars)

In short, a really complex question to tackle but we have to agree that if a car is on the road above 5-6 years, it is most probably greener to have an electric car than a gasoline one except some fringe scenarios.

Yes, it's true that nuclear power can be produced day and night, and regardless of the weather. Is nuclear power superior to solar or wind? Well, that's a matter of opinion. My opinion is that solar and wind are superior to nuclear for a whole bunch of reasons, with the top reasons being that solar and wind are completely safe, have zero impact on the environment, cost very little on both an absolute scale, as well as a relative one, and are the easiest technologies to implement--no PhD or master's degree or specialized knowledge is required.


saturnday: Renewables always suffer from downtime.
-----
Yes, renewable energy can suffer from occasional downtime, but that can be mitigated, or eliminated, with a larger capacity battery array. In addition, downtime from renewables is a minor trade-off in order to obtain all of its benefits, some of which I mentioned above. Battery technology is always improving, and in my opinion, it's the key to making solar and wind the de facto standard for current methods of commercial, or personal, energy production, as well as future methods. With improved battery technology, it'll cost less to store energy from solar or wind, and then have that stored energy be available 24/7 for either continuous or on demand use.

author: Calin Campbell

text:
@Calin Campbell No, that is no longer the case.  Circuit boards today are almost never repaired anymore, they simply get replaced.  The time and labor to troubleshoot and repair them is no longer cost effective.

Part  of the reason is surface mounted components and multi layered boards.  In the old days, you would find the defective component, remove it and solder in a new one.  This is a lot more difficult to do as the components are extremely small, are surface mounted, and the complexity of a single board is exponentially greater than before.

The wiring harness is the same.  Tracking down where the fault is and performing surgery on it is expensive and time consuming, and it is far quicker and cheaper to replace it.

I am an electronics engineer that used to do component level repairs a long time ago.  Today, that is almost unheard of except in highly specialized applications.  Circuit cards and wiring harnesses for cars are mass produced, and as such are relatively inexpensive, making it far quicker and cheaper to just replace them.

text:
@Bartonovich52 Have you EVER seen an electrical grid transformer covered in ice or snow that was NOT melting, even in the coldest temperatures?
Of course not.  Every transformer produces a lot of heat. That's why they all have absolutely HUGE oil-filled heat sinks on them.  Why Oil?  Because oils have the highest specific heat absorption capability without causing all of the corrosion problems and "shorting out the circuitry" problems caused by water.  Put your hand on one of those heat sinks, even in the dead of winter, and it will be toasty warm, if not hot.
And that 50 Hz or 60 Hz hum you hear... that's right... that's even more losses that come with your transformer.
Now I'm not disparaging the step-up and step-down transformers in our power grid -- they are the KEY to having practical electrical service more than 10 miles from a power plant.  But let's get real... they are NOT free.  They produce significant losses in the system, the same as as all the 150-year old WOODEN pipes in the Detroit Water System, leaking all over the place cause enormous losses (there are some abandoned lots in Detroit which, due to these leaks, have become literal marshlands, with typical marshland plants and animals (both 4-footed and the 2-footed flying types).
EVERY type of energy conversion, even of voltage level, brings losses with it.  EVERY SINGLE ONE.

text:
3 main reasons. 

The primary one is the cost of the battery packs. Tesla is pushing for cost savings in battery packs through MASS production of cells and packs in their partnership with Samsung. Even their own goals are to get the cost down to ~100$/kwh in a completed pack. Their top range cars have a capacity of 100kwh so that's 10,000 just for the pack. Other manufacturers are ~50-100% higher cost on batteries so even a modest 50kwh battery will cost those companies ~7k lets say.  


The second reason is production size. Cheap vehicles are cheap because they produce millions of units and when you are producing at such a mass scale you can get the costs of each part very low and keep costs down. The profit margins on those vehicles are usually VERY small (trucks are a different story, reason why companies are ditching their sedan lines heavily)  


Third is service model. Traditional manufacturers make fairly little from selling you a vehicle. (like couple percent profit margins at best). The money is in their dealership model for trade ins, used vehicle sales and maintenance. The service department in a dealership is where a huge percentage of their profits come from. With EVs having very little regular scheduled maintenance dealerships absolutely hate them because they cant survive selling them. Anyone I've talked to at Nissan dealerships loves the leaf because its a super easy sale and they sell like hotcakes but the service dept hates them with a passion because they never come in for repairs.

text:
First, I watched all your videos, they are very educational and easy to understand, and I very appreciate your work.

But there is one thing in this video I strongly disagree:
From which source or type of electrical power plant you get your electricity to charge your electric car.

Let me explain:
As shown in videos there is electricity from water, sun, wind, bio-thing, gas, oil, coal and other fossils.
Hydro, wind and sun power plants are cheapest to run because their "fuel" is basically free. Therefore - they are basically running all the time they can because of cost.
Then there is gas and nuclear power plant which are more expensive but still cheaper then fossil fuel power plants.
Proof - On US energy information administration website - Table 8.4. Average Power Plant Operating Expenses from 2007 - 2017

So, what's the catch?
Fossil fuel power plants are last in a row to firing up where there is a demand in electrical grid for electricity.
Surprisingly, still fossil power plant produce huge 31% electricity in USA!
But who is demanding extra power in grid which is cause to get electricity from fossil? Electric cars for sure! 
Because, we can't say that devices and machines which we were using before electric car were on the road are creating extra demand.
Every extra demand for electricity is cause to get those power from fossil, because all other sources of electricity are working 100% and they aren't enough!

Now would someone say, yeah, but then also my microwave get some power from fossils! That is true, but you don't have option to run your microwave on gasoline.

Also someone might say: I live in Idaho and we don't have fossil power plants! That's true, but you need to understand how electrical network works.
All states in USA are synchronised in one electrical grid and electricity doesn't know about borders of states.
Therefore if you plug in your electric car in Idaho you will probably get some electricity from Utah and Wyoming where most power come from fossil.
I live in Croatia, and most our energy comes from hydro power plants. But we can't produce enough energy for ourself and we import energy from Serbia and Bosnia&Hercegovina, where most energy comes from coal.
So when I plug in electric car, some poor guy in Bosnia is choking in bad air while eating ƒáevapi.
(ƒáevapi - traditional Bosnian food)

Conclusion: If electric cars in USA consume less than 31% of overall produced energy in country, be sure that electric cars is causing fossil power plants to work more to produce same amount of energy as needed for electric car.

@Taranisify Everything that goes into making and recycling a car can be done without emitting any CO‚ÇÇ whatsoever. It doesn't at the moment because civilization hasn't evolved fast enough as the fossil fuel industry and their dependents are desperately trying to protect their income.


You can melt down an ICE in an electric furnace powered by solar, wind or hydro etc, or in concentrated solar furnace. Mining can be (and is done by) electric bucketwheels, trains, dumper trucks and electrification is increasing. Mining companies are installing solar farms and wind turbines to power their operations instead of laying transmission lines because it's cheaper.
Lithium mining basically involves waiting for the brine to dry and then scooping up the salts. All this can be done with solar power and EVs.


There are tons of resources in the scientific literature on recycling processes, methods and refining.
Everything in a lithium cell can be recycled, so after the cathode's molecular structure degrades due to repeated cycles as lithium ions are stored and discharged and in some cases copper ions migrate into it and reduce its efficiency, it can be just dissolved, purified and remade with its original structure into new batteries with identical or better properties.
18650 cell casings are made of nickel - these are also made into new cases.
Lead in old lead acid batteries are easy to recycle, and lead sulphate can be converted back into lead.
It's fortunate that the ingredients only need to be mined once, and then can be (almost) infinitely recycled.

text:
This is a great bit of research and a good contribution to the debate. I'm going to challenge two of your assumptions: the electrical generation mix and the state to state variation.

Using the national average electrical generation mix is inappropriate. Increasing or decreasing electricity usage is not going to affect the amount of hydro power generation. No-one is going to spill the dam water because you didn't plug in your car.
Energy for your E-car comes from gas, coal or (potentially) nuclear, depending on circumstances. During the day, marginal electrical generation comes from gas. During the night, most baseline power comes from coal. (In the long term, if America starts making different choices, the power might come from nuclear but not yet.) That means the most appropriate calculation is something like the West Virginia mix, with the best case payback time of 5 years.
As for the state-by-state variation, that's a fallacy, too. We all live on the grid. When you plug in your electric car in Idaho, that Joule of hydro is taken from someone else who now has to get his Joule from out-of-state. Transmission losses and costs moderate this argument a bit but probably not much.
author: Peter Enns

text: So you're simply going to ignore that energy production has historically gotten greener with time, and say that we should only look at West Virginia's energy mix as a model, yet ignore the state-by-state variation? I'm not sure what you're countering.
author: Engineering Explained

text:
@Engineering Explained Thanks for your reply. 
I am sure not recommending  W. Virginia's energy mix as a model (except in the mathematical sense ;-) I am arguing that we need to think in terms of MARGINAL COST instead of average cost. That's why I use the example of Hydro. It's everyone's favorite electricity source but you can't have more of it. All the best rivers are taken. Using more electricity will not affect the amount of hydro generation so it is irrelevant to marginal cost.
Sadly, that principle holds more generally. Whatever our favorite source is, its production is probably constrained. Otherwise, we would make more of it. That means that (in the absence of contrary details), using more electricity means using your least favorite source. In the short-to-medium term, the marginal source is a mix of coal and (through lucky happenstance) gas.

PS. If I have your attention, I'd love to tell you my objective measure for engine flexibility. 
Elevator pitch: horespower@xxxx rpm and torque@yyyy rpm is a poor way way to judge the width of an engine's powerband. Instead, we should publish its "three-quarter power window". I think there is an interesting Engineering Explained episode to be had. Reply if you want more detail.

text:
Your math is incorrect. You're subtracting 5% then 10% then 15% from 100%, but you're forgetting that those losses have occurred while subtracting the subsequent percentages. 5+10+15=30, and 100-30=70, but that isn't what's actually occurring because you're not dealing with whole numbers, your dealing with percentages which are not whole numbers, they're fractions.

First you have 100% of the energy in something that the power plant uses to generate electricity, but it loses 5% of that energy in the process, leaving you with 95% turned into electricity. Next you have the AC to DC conversion loss of 10%, but you're only losing 10% of the 95% that remains from the losses at the power plant, so you're not losing 10% of the original input energy, you're losing 10% of 95%, which is only 9.5% of the original input. This leaves you with 85.5% of the original, rather than the 85% you were calculating. Next you lose another 15%, but it's not 15% of the original 100% input energy, because you've already lost 14.5% of that upstream, so you're only losing 15% of the remaining 85.5%, which doesn't leave you with 70%, it leaves you with 72.675%, which is nearly 3% more than your calculation showed.

I'm only using your numbers because those are what you showed, and the real numbers are different than those, but you'd still be making that basic mathematical calculation error even if you had the real numbers, and it's that error that you need to correct the most, because you'll get EVERY calculation wrong if you don't, not just this one. Remember that when you're calculating something using a sequence of separate equations and passing the output of one to the next equation in the chain, you have to calculate the actual output of each upstream equation before adding in the effects of the next equation in the sequence, otherwise you're factoring out all of the necessary equations and just adding your variables together independent of the necessary math. It's a very easy error to make for anyone who doesn't depend on math for a living, tons and tons of people do this, even people who you wouldn't think would do it, and sometimes even people who others depend on to get their math right, like politicians and business operators who think that raising the minimum wage will not benefit anyone because the higher costs will more than offset the increase in wages, even though mathematically the opposite is true. But now that you know that lesson, you'll never have to make that mistake again as long as you remember the lesson and take care in your math to calculate everything in the correct order.

text:
I do like your videos and I think you have done a pretty thorough job on this. However, I don't think you are making the fairest comparison. By comparing an EV like the Nissan Leaf to the average gasoline car in the US, I think you are stacking the odds in favour of the EV. Don't get me wrong, I am all for EVs but I think you need to compare like for like. 
The Leaf is a c.1,500kg, 80kW car so for a true comparison it should be compared directly to a new gasoline car of similar mass and power output. My experience with the US car market is that the average gasoline car in the US is far heavier than 1,500kg and more powerful than 80kW. This is further skewed by a reasonably high concentration of gasoline powered trucks in the US compared to other countries which will naturally have higher emissions due to much higher mass, larger frontal area and large capacity engines. 
I realise that the Department of Energy source does not make any distinction like this so it makes finding a non-biased source of emissions for specific vehicles more difficult. Something to consider though.

Stuck power windows, aircon playing up, power steering giving issues.
All that is present in electric vehicles and Tesla has been notorious for issues with these components.

In my opninion the greenest solution is to switch to greener liquid fuel - i.e. grown from algae to avoid destroying even more land.

text:
@Matt Lane radioactive steam releases? Are you talking about the once in a blue moon that a nuclear plant may vent an immeasurable amount of steam as part of their hydrogen buildup mitigation techniques? The like once in a decade release that is required to be stored so that 95% of the radioactivity that may be in it is nearly immeasurable? The release that the EPA regulates so tightly that it can only be done so as to minimize the release? That release? Completely negligible to the environment....  not even measurable outside of some seriously sensitive equipment and is extremely short lived... less than a year. 

Tritium exists in nature... it has a silly short half life of 8 days in the human body and 12 years in the wild. Releases from power plants is again extremely small. You are exposed to more tritium by walking down the back hallways of your work near the emergency exit signs than has every been released by a "leaking" nuclear plant...

The fuel rods are indeed highly radioactive. No doubt about it. They aren't water soluble, they don't readily burn and are extremely hard to move without someone noticing. As far as a waste stream is concerned, they are about perfect... no gases to worry about, no melting to worry about, no turning into giant radioactive rivers of ash mud (coal fly ash piles)... as far as radioactive emissions are concerned, spent nuclear fuel isn't even on the radar. Radon releases from natural gas is.  Thorium, uranium, polonium, lead, and radon from coal absolutely are though....  in significantly higher quantities with near zero regulation. 

As for SNF's radioactivity, 95% of SNF is U238 which is no more radioactive today than the day it came out of the ground. About 1% is plutonium and other trans uranic elements which are conveniently fissile or fertile (meaning they can be used as fuel).  The remaining 4% are fission products that are the real source of the radiation risk of SNF... the longest lived of which is made in extremely small quantities and emits less radiation than background radiation. The vast majority of what is left has half lives of about 30 years or less.  That means storing for 300 years if we reprocess everything else out. 

Furthermore, long half lives are actually desirable from a waste handling perspective. There are only so many ways for something to decay via radiation... those methods have known every values and risks but suffice to say if you have 500 atoms of two elements with one having a 5 year half life and the other a 5 million year half life and both decay by alpha decay... the first will dump the shine amount of energy in 5 years as the second will in 5 million... so longer half lives means less risk to people and the environment from a radiation standpoint.  This is easily demonstrated by giving you a sample of uranium 238 which has an extremely long half life of 4.468 billion years and comparing that to something like xenon 135 with a half life of 9.2 hours... the uranium will only kill you if you eat it because of its chemical toxicity... the radiation would take several lifetimes to kill you compared to the toxicity of eating a heavy metal.  The xenon would just kill you nearly instantly from radiation sickness....

All of the studies make the same mistake.   The average CO2 emissions produced by the electric grid is irrelevant.  When you charge an EV you are not using average power.  You are asking the grid to produce power in addition to what is currently being produced.   So, you have to look at where the incremental increase in power comes from.

All of the non-petroleum power plants run at 100% meaning there is no additional non-petroleum capacity available to meet the additional load of charging the EV.   They don't cover up solar panels or stop the wind generators when demand drops, they throttle down the petroleum plants and leave the non-petroluem sources producing all the power they can. You did a great job of considering all factors, here.  Well done!

There‚Äôs one very important consideration you may not have made clear enough though, or at least some could easily misinterpret:  One of the very few cases where a gas car would beat an EV, as you pointed out, would be if you buy a large-batteried EV and then drive it for two years in West Virginia (a pretty-much coal-powered State).  That would only be true if you sold that vehicle after two years *for scrap*!  In almost all cases though, that car will instead be sold to a second owner, who will continue to recoup that one-time carbon-emissions penalty of battery production.  In other words, it‚Äôs not a matter of how long you keep the car after you buy it, but how long the car continues to be driven after manufacture.

But it goes even further than that:  after 10-15 years, say, when the car becomes undrivable, it‚Äôs battery cells will then be harvested for use in stationary power systems, further amortizing that one-time chunk of carbon emissions.  By then, economical recycling for Li-Ion batteries will have emerged.

text:
Sebbuz11:  Ultimately, the task at hand is to create a small set of machine types that can ‚Äúde-manufacture‚Äù battery cells.  Mostly, that‚Äôs about reducing the number of types of cell to be dealt with.  It‚Äôs really hard to create a machine that can de-manufacture 200 different types of batteries.

So, what comes in the door is a large, multi-module battery used at a 400KW fast-DC EV charger, or at an office building as UPS, or at a large solar array to supply power at night when the array clearly can‚Äôt.  It‚Äôs one of several-to-many refrigerator-sized boxes of battery cells from that site, found to be not performing up-to-spec anymore, thus to be ‚Äúend-of-lifed.‚Äù  That, after 20 years in that role, in turn after 10-15 years time spent in an EV.  The battery cells in that box are all of the same type, having all come from Tesla Model 3 cars originally, or at least they are each one of 3-4 very-similar types.  Even better, the box contains about 30,000 cells ‚Äî a ‚Äúbountiful harvest,‚Äù so to speak.  

First, factory workers and their machines disassemble the physical boxes, remove the battery modules, and remove the individual cells from the modules.  Currently, we can‚Äôt do much more than that economically, but 20 years from now, they will feed the individual cells into the ‚ÄúTesla 2170 de-manufacturing machine,‚Äù which peels off the metal casing, washes out the electrolyte, separates and cleans the graphite anode, unwinds the cathode, made of a combination of metals.  It melts down the cathode metals and separates them out, and separates out the electrolyte materials.  

That‚Äôs a pretty doable de-manufacturing machine.

In the case of personal electronics, however, you have battery cells in the hands of 100s of millions of individual consumers.  Of the way-too-few that don‚Äôt end up in a landfill, they somehow have to be collected together, at a cost.  Among them, there are of ~300 different physical form factors (physical dimensions) and probably 5 different, largely-incompatible battery chemistries.  It‚Äôs really hard to create a battery-cell de-manufacturing machine for that huge a variety of cell types, if you can even get them to a de-manufacturing plant cost-effectively.

text:
I respect what you are trying to do, but it really is best to leave this issue to experts. The average plugin electric car only has an 11% higher combined thermal cycle efficiency. You cannot talk about electric vehicle emissions, without also discussing grid efficiency/emissions. Just going to the EPA website, and quoting some numbers doesn‚Äôt even come close to explaining the issue.

For starters the EPA website uses the GREET model, which has been criticized for favoring electric energy by using equivalent CO2, and then basing those numbers on the complete oil cycle (well to wheel), but not on the complete coal cycle (especially coal derived from mountain top removal), effectively making the equivalent number less than it actually is for electricity. It has also been widely criticized for using industry data with no accuracy requirement, like the EIA and other government agencies have. They also under reported direct land use GHG emissions from corn production for almost a decade, further perpetuating the idea that ethanol has a lower environmental impact than gasoline, when in fact it does not.

A simple efficiency analysis in excel, using EIA data (that does have accuracy requirements), and some standard motor, battery, and drivetrain efficiency data, would be far more informative, and easier to understand. It would also put the problem into a rational perspective, comparing only a few simple cases to the entire US energy market, rather than vague, net positive eCO2 formulas.
When it comes to the grid, and the power plants in it, they are old, dirty, and inefficient. No amount of analysis will make putting more energy thought it a good idea. I‚Äôm sure you can understand that models are not reality, only our best guess at it. When it comes to hard decisions, like where to build a factory, or which car to buy, it is best to stick with hard data. Using models created by other agencies, using data from industry sources, only creates more question than it answers.

First off, I would assume that it would have something to do with emissions, now I am not a professional in this at all, so take that or leave. I will also assume for the sake of the argument I am going to make that your comment about a "... diesel engine makes you impotent..." is correct (which it may well not be correct!).

As for the point I want to set out to make... It isn't that it WILL make someone impotent, it is that the CHANCE is higher that it will... When a Tobacco company says (or used to say) that "There is no proof that smoking cigarettes causes cancer!" they are, from a pure logic stand point correct! This is because the only time you can really prove something is in mathematics (generally speaking from my understanding)...

You can have an overwhelming pile of evidence that said activity may lead to or cause another, but that is all it is from a pure logic standpoint. Now do I (and I assume most people) think that the argument and TREMENDOUS PILE OF EVIDENCE that smoking causes cancer is correct? Yes. In everyday speak we call it (very) strong evidence or "proof".

To conclude, you are correct that "... pretty much then everything is bad for everything...". (I assume you mean that everything can be bad for you right?) However, drinking too much water can kill you as well, it doesn't mean you stop drinking water. You just don't drinks gallons of it in the course of minutes to an hour! If you know there is a high risk that some action will cause a bad result, you (typically) aren't going to take that risk. However you can try to minimize the risk. An everyday example would be instead of lifting by leaning over and having all the load on your back it would be safer FOR MOST PEOPLE to squat down and "use their legs" to do the lifting instead of their back... However that risk will probably be magnified if you are picking up a 50 to 100 pound package as opposed to picking up a dollar you have found on the ground (I also make the assumption that in both cases the circumstances is the same, you are lifting the package or the dollar off of a sidewalk for example...).

text:
As much as I enjoy your channel, this is outside the realm of the hard sciences, or on the other end of the scale the opinion based on balance of probability you normally deliver (such as your "Italian tune-up" the other week - BTW we called it "The apprentice tune-up" when I was on the tools. But I digress). It's a field shrouded in inference and half-truths and intentionally misleading. For these reasons, I must put my oar in.

1:18 Citations used to mean something. But just citing even a peer reviewed study simply doesn't carry the weight it used to. There is corruption to the system. We live in a post-truth era. Simply failing to 'toe the company line' regularly sees people lose their livelihoods.

1:47 Ignoring EOL emissions seems on the surface to be reasonable, considering the small proportion the make up relative to manufacturing and use emissions. However, this means you also neglect the frequency of the emissions and assume that both vehicles have a similar lifespan. I would argue that an ICE vehicle has a considerably longer lifespan given advancements in technology are not occurring anywhere near quite so dramatically and frequently so disposal of EVs would be at a higher rate as people move to vehicles with greater range etc. Age and mileage is not such a factor when they see that if they don't 'upgrade' now their old technology EV will be almost worthless soon with superior technology appearing. Wait a little too long in a fast moving technological landscape such as this and that EV will indeed be scrapped well before the ICE.
 
4:15 Emissions for producing the battery. Is this just the actual manufacturing process, or does this also include the emissions from all the steps of materials mining and procurement?

5:02 This table showing 5.2T of CO2 per year is for the AVERAGE petrol vehicle. The average petrol vehicle is NOT the same as the average EV. The average petrol vehicle would be larger with more load carrying capacity. I've yet to see an electric utility (pickup truck) vehicle. Unless you can isolate the comparable vehicles to obtain the correct figure, it is a clear disadvantage to the ICE vehicles in the same usage as the EVs. Your following example of the 4x4 pickup truck is a case in point. Its higher than average emissions indicate that vehicles in the same category of EVs (generally smaller hatchbacks) would have lower than average emissions.

11:27 People and equipment need to be located in these remote lithium mining locations too. People need food which must be shipped in which takes energy and generates emissions... you see where I'm going, right?.

One critical thing that you've overlooked is the capital cost. Sure, directly, it's not related to emissions. But the high capital cost of EVs is a factor that may cause people to vary their other emissions producing activities. They may, because of the cost of debt servicing, chose not to purchase so-called 'green' foodstuffs - that is, more expensive virtue signalling low food miles foodstuffs. Or 'sustainably farmed' nonsense. There is an offset to this from the lower EV running costs. But the question remains as to what activities detrimental to their 'carbon footprint' will be suspended. Or perhaps they're well heeled and the savings from the lower EV running costs will simply mean more overseas holidays... flying there and back, of course. What I'm saying is what are the unintended consequences of people buying EVs that could in fact overall make their individual emissions no better or indeed worse? Given the claim is this is a global problem, we need to look at the scenarios holistically.

Of course, all this CO2 emissions nonsense is predicated on the belief that CO2 is bad for the environment (greenhouse effect, acidification of oceans etc.) and we must curb our emissions by giving our money away as extra taxes.

I simply don't buy it. The strongest advocates for 'climate change' (or whatever it's called this week) are hypocrites, even if you ignore the celebrities, as I do. Just look at Al Gore's carbon footprint. Of course, some will justify it because he's generating it bringing the message to the peasants. I say bollocks. Look up the Intergenerational Wealth organisation.

CO2 has been much, much higher in the past - long before man was around. CO2 is plant food - the more CO2 the more plants converting it to oxygen and storing the evil carbon. Even assuming CO2 is bad, given it only contributes 20% to the greenhouse effect, and human emissions are responsible for about 4% of the annual CO2, by my calculations if all human CO2 emissions ceased tomorrow, that's a reduction of 0.8% of the greenhouse effect (0.20 x 0.04). If you're really worried about the effect of man on the planet, lead by example and...

STOP BREEDING JUST TO SATISFY YOUR SELFISH URGE TO REPRODUCE.

Ozone being at the top of the atmosphere is irrelevant - it's still around 700 times less abundant than CO2 yet manages to block a large proportion of UV light. I'm showing you how crap your "0.04%" argument is. What looks like a tiny quantity to a layman can have a massive impact in reality.

The Little Ice Age was in part caused by decreased solar activity. We're currently in a period of decreasing solar activity, yet the temperature continues to rise. How do you explain that, if not with CO2?

Without human activity, yes. A natural increase in temperature causes CO2 and other greenhouse gasses to be released from oceans, swamps, ice caps etc. Which then causes further warming and a positive feedback loop until a new equilibrium is found. What humans are doing is skipping the step that requires natural warming through Milankovic Cycles, we're just directly adding CO2 to the atmosphere, which causes warming, more CO2 to be released, etc.
Think of it this way - a fire can cause an increase in temperature, but an increase in temperature can also cause a fire. Things don't always work just one way.

Global warming was first predicted many decades before Al Gore was born. It's such a lame argument when people bring him up. I don't care what a politician says; he's irrelevant to the discussion.

text:
A good video, probably the most thorough I have seen on the subject. That said, it misses, as all studies do, the emissions involved in getting gas/diesel into the tank of ICE vehicles. EPA emission ratings only tell us what is actually measured at the tailpipe. They do not account for all of the emissions involved in finding, drilling,  shipping to refineries, refining, shipping to regional storage, shipping to filling stations and finally pumping into the vehicle's tank. These emissions are much higher in the case of oil sands crude which requires enormous machinery to dig and haul the oar, and very dirty and emission intensive processing to separate the bitumen from the sand. Refineries require enormous amounts of electricity. So much so that they require their own sub-stations. A gallon of gasoline uses as much as 6kwh of electricity. That much electricity would take me 25 miles in my EV.
Another important point missed here, is that EV batteries can be used for in-home storage and other uses after their time of powering cars is over.

text:
@William Barker 
CO2? It's interesting...
The population of Europe is ~743 million in 2018. 6.38 tonnes CO2 produced per capita in 2014.
The population of the USA is ~327 million in 2018. 16.49 tonnes CO2 produced per capita in 2016.
The USA relies heavily on coal and natural gas for energy production, but also generates ~21% from nuclear with a low CO2 emission. Green/renewable energy sources are gaining momentum however, now making up ~18% in 2018.
Many countries in Europe have significant amounts of green/renewable energy (since many years now) and also significant nuclear. But there are also poorer European countries that rely heavily on gas and coal and will do for some decades to come. Even the likes of France and Germany still use significant natural gas for heating of buildings and domestic hot water.
The 'Total' CO2 emissions of Europe vs. USA are likely to be quite similar in 2018, with fully up to date figures. Per capita... it's a different story however.

text:
The scale does not work for India or China because they do not burn coal as cleanly as American plants do, relatively speaking.   I don't think you realize what an underground mine is. An underground mine is where a large diameter hole  30 feet by 30 feet square is blasted into rock down to a level where an orebody can be mined and auxiliary infrastructure that makes mining possible can be built, like sumps to trap water and fine materials from drilling into ore for example.  This 30 foot by 30 foot hole ( some are much larger) go down 10,000 feet or more (19,000 feet in South Africa). The nickel mine I work at is 4,400 feet deep, and mining has gone down lower by way of ramp to 4,750 feet. To give you some idea about what it takes to build a mine I'll describe the activities.
#1 a helicopter flies over wilderness carrying a magnetometer to search for metallics.
#2 a team of geologists hits the ground collecting "grab samples" of rock for analysis.(Fuel to heat tents and power quads and boats)
#3 a diamond drilling rig is hauled up by truck or flown in by helicopter( Aviation fuel) to drill and delineate a possible ore body. (diesel)
#4 A small camp is built and materials for it are trucked in or flown in ( fossil fuels)
#5 after a couple of years of economic feasibility studies a decision is made to build a mine.Many millions of gallons of fossil fuels are required to truck or fly stuff in...and to operate the mine.
    Oil on the other hand is where people assemble a drill rig, drill a hole the size of a 2 foot pipe until they hit oil. It's slightly different for fracking. And it is much more fossil fuels intensive for deep sea oil rigs...but once they have a rig they can just move it anywhere...you can't move a shaft in rock is the point I would make. So for each oilfield the drilling equipment is mobile, but for each nickel orebody, nothing is reusable elsewhere except men and mobile equipment. A new shaft through rock everytime they want to mine.

text:
You've had a 'modern' EV battery for more than 10 years?  hardly.  Degradation from e.g. EV Taxies show that battery degradation is (iirc) somewhere between 5-10% per 100,000 miles...  meaning an EV with a 300 mile range would only manage 270 miles after 100k (or about 8 years based on the 'average' mileage used in the video).

What often gets overlooked is how much the power and economy of petrol engines drop over similar mileage.  An 'old & worn out' petrol engine won't make the same power (or fuel economy figures) that it did when factory-fresh, and thus will have less range per tank of fuel... but this always seems to be ignored... funny that.

On the upside, if/when the battery does need to be replaced, it can be recycled with ~99% efficiency...  and given the cost-per-kw for batteries is falling year-on-year, in 10 years time (or whenever the battery is too degraded) replacing the battery should be cheaper (and/or get you more capacity/range)

text:
Are electric cars worse for the environment? Yes, yes they are. 
Ignore carbon; CO2 is a magic gas that makes plants grow, and Planet Earth is currently in a period of carbon drought so stop worrying about your car's carbon emissions; humans only create a tiny, tiny amount of carbon compared to nature anyway.

What is the lifespan of an electric car? There's a 100,000 mile warranty on the battery, but performance and range will diminish over time to about 70% and that 8 year warranty only kicks in when capacity drops below 70%. It's not a deal breaker but once the battery performance drops below a usable level and can't be trusted to get you to work and home again, the car is scrap.

Price difference: Freaking huge. Most people cannot even think about buying an electric car. You might say that the saving in fuel costs will make up the difference, but (a) for people who only travel short distances it is more economical to use a petrol car since most of the cost is in the car not the fuel, and (b) TAXES! In the UK, more than HALF the cost of fuel is tax; petrol and diesel would be a lot cheaper otherwise. Could electric cars compete against half-price fuel? When there are no more petrol and diesel cars for the Government to extract money from, who do you think they'll turn their eyes on next? Electric cars will be super-taxed.

Pollution: Let's not ignore that end of life issue, because it does factor in. Carbon is no big deal, but what do you do with a half-ton of lithium battery? Multiply that by one billion cars. 

Lithium as a non-renewable resource: Current stockpiles are about 40 million tons, which is enough to last a long time but each car uses somewhere between 4 to 14 kilos of lithium. One day the lithium will run out, and it'll run out before oil does.

text: Jason, I'm very sorry but I have to give you a thumbs down as you've made a very common and critical mistake when comparing an ICE car to an EV car when comparing emissions. The rest of the video is good so it's a shame that this is bringing down the whole video. You have to compare apples to apples to make it a fair comparison but you are simply not doing that. You are comparing the emissions while running of the ICE vehicle with the emissions to generate the electricity used to run the EV. Either you compare the emissions tail pipe emissions (running cost) of the ICE vs EV. Or you compare the emissions of the energy used to power the vehicles so in the case of the ICE car, this is the total emissions to find, extract/drill, transport, refine, transport again and store the fossil fuel before it is pumped into the vehicle. In the case of the EV, this would be working out the emission cost to generate the electricity used to charge the vehicle.

text:
Let's say you use a generator to convert oil/ gasoline into electric energy with a net efficiency of 65%, and then stored in other batteries or directly distributed for use. Taking into account efficiency losses in the process, an EV will be able to convert about 90% of that chemical energy into motion, and considering other losses totalling in 80% efficiency, 65%*80%=52%, meaning 52% of the chemical energy initially found in the gasoline/ fuel is converted into motion for the EV, which is significantly greater that 40% (at most) thermal efficiency of an ICE.
Of course I mean using some kind of generator since there are no possibilities to create an engine of this type to be fitted in a vehicle.
Note that this is not a solution in the long run, as it would be "greener" to use energy coming from renewable resources, but can be a mid-term possibility to make a more efficient use of fossil fuels.

text: You touched on it, but I don't think you gave a complete picture of the environmental impact of battery production. You mentioned that cobalt and nickel are more common than lithium, and that they are more recyclable, but that doesn't mean there isn't record demand for freshly mined cobalt, nickel, etc today.  Most of the world's supply of cobalt comes from the Congo. Child labor is near epidemic, groundwater, rivers and streams are so polluted that the water is undrinkable and no good for irrigation. Cobalt dust is causing respiratory illness for miners and children are being born with high numbers of birth defects .  Scientists have also sited alarming radiation levels because uranium also litters some cobalt mining sites. Nickel is extracted through strip mining, and the processing of nickel emits lead, arsenic and hydrogen sulfide, among a long list of other less than environmentally friendly chemicals. In some places, so much sediment has made it into waterways,  entire ecosystems have been destroyed as part of the mining process. Extracting Lithium from the environment does its share of environmental damage too, which you did mention, but it is the least impactful of the the 3 metals mentioned here.
