None of any of this matters.  Electric cars still cost FAR too much on initial purchase and a replacement battery is a MASSIVE expense.  It STILL takes at LEAST 11 years to reach ROI on electric vs ICE.  If someone has to pay more, then the reality is that the thing actually took WAY more energy to make.  Both by way of the materials and by way of all the more people involved down the chain of production.  I can't get a GenX Civic all electric EX Sedan for the same price as what I paid even if such a thing existed.  I would pay a 25% premium if I knew that I would never pay for gas again but that is not even the difference in an equivalent people mover right now.  My EX Sedan cost me $30,000 on the road in Canadian.  The ONLY things that are in the same general bracket of functionality and size are the Bolt and really, the Model 3.  The Model 3 is only available for a whopping $91,000 after tax in Canada.  Even the Bolt would be $60 grand on the road.  I would be further ahead to STILL get the Civic and put solar on my house with the other $30,000.  Even in the magical world of Tesla selling the $35k USD M3, that is still almost $55,000 Canadian after tax.  NO NO NO NO...  (Even the Honda Clarity plugin hybrid (Basically a Civic) is FAR too expensive to have a reasonable ROI for average duration of ownership) (Also note that the Prius Plugin lacks all of the radar and camera systems that my Civic has AND still costs over $46,000 Canadian on the road)

When the decision is SAME price (And ALL same features) or +10% and it is between a slower refill by say 10 minutes vs 5 for gasoline.  Done and done.  I will buy an electric without pause.  The VAST majority of people are NOT super wealthy virtue signaling celebrities or YouTube stars.  We live normal lives making average salaries and have to be careful with our money or someone doesn't eat or a bill goes unpaid and your credit score goes to hell.

And don't get me wrong.  Electric motors are indeed the future.  The issue is that batteries are not.  Graphene based capacitors are the only truly viable solution.  Even fuel cells have issues as far as getting the hydrogen into the market.  A capacitor powered world is a vastly more efficient world with no sacrifices in speed to refill your energy in ANY application.  They are the fastest to charge and have a MASSIVE life expectancy compared to batteries.  They are also FAR less damaging to the environment to make and are actually biodegradable.

If you have the money to virtue signal, then you likely live a life that is already generating a LOT of CO2 in many other completely avoidable ways. (Vacations, overly large houses, too many personal belongings, etc...)

The grid is already having major issues in places like California where they are experiencing blackouts. the idea of a grid that can support a electrical car dominated market is just not true. also co2 is no longer the major concern in California for the utility companies that are in charge of power distribution. Southern edison and pge have realized that there are massive leaks of natural gas escaping their pipe systems. The reason this is a big deal is methane gas. Considered to be much worse that co2 the state is doing everything it can to find the leaks. Also the construction costs and time needed to pass new grid systems like transmission power generation and distribution systems is massively long. It can take many years to build new ones through all the red tape. I have seen projects postponed for many years due to the red tape of permits. 

Finally there is a big problem with renewable energy generation. Considerably more expensive and not very efficient for what's needed in numbers of wind turbines or solar panels. The amount of windmills produced by California alone which numbers the hundreds is still only creating 5.5 gigawatts as of 2017 and the grand coulee dam itself creates 21 gigawatts. So we have some major problems already with the power grid due to finances. Environmental impact like natural gas and no more new hydro or nuclear so we are stuck with you guessed it. Building more natural gas power plants and coal. Not good.

text: @Nicholas Larson Repeating a false claim does not make it true.  Sure, methane is a more powerful greenhouse gas than CO2, but burning methane for electricity is better than burning coal -- because burning coal produces far more than just CO2.  Coal plants emit nitrates, sulfates, volatile organics, and a variety of particulates in addition to CO2 -- and produce piles of toxic coal-ash as a byproduct.  Fortunately, the US grid overall is using less and less coal; it is being replaced by several different (Combined Cycle Natural Gas, Thermal Solar, Photovoltaic Solar, On-shore Wind, Off-shore Wind, etc) power sources.  The overall percentage power on the national grid from non-carbon sources (currently around 20%, if I recall correctly) is steadily growing -- and the cost to build a GW of PV Solar and/or Wind power production is now less expensive than building new Coal, Nuclear, or Natural Gas plants.  Not only will the US inevitably get to a zero-carbon grid, it will get there quicker than naysayers predict, because it is driven by simple economics.

text:
@Andr√°s B√≠r√≥ Wind and solar are actually not very good at decarbonizing electricity. In fact, once they produce above a few percent of total generation on a given grid, they start to lock in fossil fuel use because they are utterly dependent on something to provide backup power when they don't produce anything, or don't produce as much as expected. If you look at German GHG emissions from their energy sector over the past 18 years, you'll see they've barely budged even though they've been busy building windmills and installing solar panels as fast as they can. What renewables are good at is causing retail prices of electricity to rise. See for example places like Denmark, Germany and California. Rising electricity prices make EVs less economically attractive.

What has been making electricity less CO2 intensive in the US and other places around the world is natural gas, which has been displacing even more CO2 intensive coal. The only instances of regions and nations in the developed world in which electricity has been almost entirely decarbonized are France, Sweden and Ontario, and they achieved this through a mix of nuclear power and hydroelectricity. In France and Sweden's case, the process took about 20 years. Germany, by contrast, is nowhere even remotely close to decarbonizing its electricity.

author: CMG30

text:
@CMG30 The storage utilities are building doesn't turn wind and solar into "baseload". To do that would require amounts of storage that would be astronomically expensive. The storage they're building is there for frequency regulation and to reduce the ramp rates required by backup generation for times when wind and solar abruptly stop producing power (which in the case of solar happens every day when the sun goes down). Where it is economical to do so, sometimes storage can provide some peaking power.

The amount of storage needed to make wind and solar "baseload" and dispatchable would carry a pricetag measurable in multiples of national GDP.
author: Marmocet

text:
@CMG30 As to the rest of your post, renewables make the price of electricity rise because they're intermittent sources of power that need to be backed up 100% by generation that can be turned on and off on demand. In otherwords, renewables can't replace other forms of generation. They can only be added on in addition to other forms of generation. This means that adding renewables to the grid reduces the amount of power of other types of generation can sell without also reducing their fixed costs. Reducing the amount of power these other generators can sell without reducing their fixed costs (which would be the case of other generators could simply be retired and removed from the grid) means that other generators need to charge higher rates for the power they produce in order to cover their fixed costs. 

There are other reasons renewables cause the price of electricity to rise, but this is the main channel (at least for now, while their overall market penetration in most places remains quite low). The other reasons are all related to the same thing though: renewables have low capacity factors, and adding them to the grid lowers the capacity utilization of everything on the grid, from generators to transmission, to storage.
author: Marmocet

text:
Marmocet  For Solar, not really. Electricity consumption from industry peaks during the day. You can easily have 20-30% solar in your grid without being particularly encouraging of fossil fuels, even without storage, if the rest of your power comes from baseload sources.

Imho, a near optimal balance for the US with some storage would likely be 40% ish from solar, 40% ish from nuclear, 15-20% ish from hydro. Solar has the advantage that you can build it much faster than new nuclear plants which tend to require a decade or more of planning and political support. Solar can be done entirely by the private sector without help from the government, so it's politically easier to make happen quickly.

text:
Apart from brushing over the issue of battery production, including supply chain, and the current hugely inefficient state of artificially promoted EV and energy-generating technology, this video spends the majority of its time appearing to suggest that CO2 emission is of any significance. To explain reality: CO2 is not a pollutant.

When battery tech is developed to the state of being zip-chargeable and capable of containing enough energy to compete with a liquid-fuelled vehicle of an identical weight, there will be a pivot towards electric formats, but, in the meantime, the only advantage is in replacing vehicles that produce diesel particulates in cities. Hydrogen-fuel-cell technology has been somewhat suppressed, though it solves many of the issues of both classic combustion engines and EVs. It should also be noted that the harmful effects associated with diesel fumes and other genuine pollutants were exacerbated by regulators who forced the motor industry to conform to hysterical CO2 restrictions, which spawned the switch from petrol to overdeveloped diesel in most domestic vehicles, thereby making Europe's cities far more unhealthy over decades than would have been the case if petrol-engine development had not been sidelined.

To sum up: In the interim before a paradigm shift in lightweight, high-capacity, quick-charge battery tech, (and assuming the corrupting influence of politics for profit plays no part in diverting us from the most sensible and effective personal choices) companies should consider unleashing the sales potential of hydrogen-power, as well as researching the benefits of turbine-hybrids for commercial long-haul and passenger-transport applications. As far as I can tell, the simple concept of a turbine generator feeding an electric motor drivetrain has not been implemented in the haulage industry, yet it would seem to offer massive advantages in any sector where high-torque vehicles are operated for long periods without being switched off.

text:
Hydrogen fuel has waaay more steps (and thus points of lost efficiency) that straight electric. Think about it, 1) you need electricity to split water so that's only as efficient as your grid is. 2) Then you need more electricity to pump the hydrogen into storage and keep it there. 3) Then you need energy to transport it to filling stations, more energy spent. 4) Once in your car you have efficiency losses for either combustion or fuel cell operation.

Meanwhile a purely EV just draws straight from the grid. And then it's as efficient as you electric motor or motor/inverter (which for Tesla is ~90% iirc). Why spend/lose energy in all the extra steps of hydrogen? An EV is ready to go after the first step, 1) electricity from grid, ready to go. Battery EV is just a better use of electricity than Hydrogen EV.

Ignore the emissions and environmental issues. Forget gasoline, hydrogen, biofuels, coal, hydro, etc.

Bottom line: our devices and equipment all need power. Do you want each device generating its own power, or should all our power needs be generated centrally? 

Imagine a world where power is generated centrally, and all your power-hungry equipment and devices tap into that central power via electricity (through wires, induction, microwaves, batteries, capacitors, whatever).

Now imagine a world where we don't generate power centrally, instead each individual piece of equipment has its own small engine, fuel tank, and exhaust.

Which makes more sense?

text:
Just the other day, I saw an interview with a researcher at the Argonne National Laboratory talking about how there is a lot of room for improving the fuel efficiency of ICEVs, and that getting them to 75 mpg should be a pretty realistic goal. That's roughly in line with what Mazda seem to think is achievable as well. 75 mpg is equivalent to ~74g CO2/km. Assuming the same average American driver profile and including upstream emissions from refining and delivering the gasoline, that would mean emitting 2 metric tons of CO2 per year, rather than the current average of 5.4 metric tons. 

Putting newer, more fuel efficient engines in a hybrid drivetrain should be enough to get vehicle emissions down to about as low as they need to be if BEVs never get good enough or cheap enough to displace IC engines entirely. If not, there are ways we can make hydrocarbon fuels less CO2 intensive, like for example, blending CO2 neutral synthetic hydrocarbons into fossil gasoline and diesel fuel.

text:
@Joe Johnson first of CO2 is absolutely a pollutant.  The carbon cycle is balanced in nature between production and storage, however humans are inputting more carbon (in for the form of CO2 and CH4) into the atmosphere which is taking the carbon cycle out of equilibrium. There is too much production for the natural environment to absorb and store. Combine that with compounding factors such as deforestation and you have a serious problem.

CO2 absorbs longwave radiation specifically in the infra-red spectrum. Longwave radiation is the result of solar energy hitting the earth surface and reflecting it back into space. Thus a small amount of the reflected solar radiation is stored in the atmosphere as heat. This is the very definition of a pollutant - a substance or energy that is put into a system that has undesirable or adverse effects.

Now, you want to talk about other pollutants. Sure, ICE produce NOx, CH4 and SO2. All of these are potent greenhouse gases. An electric vehicle produces very little of these emissions and the only real source would be from power generation used to charge the batteries.

We can also look at volatile organic matter, particulate matter 10 um (PM10) and PM2.5 all of which are only produced by ICE and not electric vehicles and are a key component of poor air quality, respiratory issues and premature deaths. 

Lastly, photochemical smog is primarily composed of ozone (O3) which is a byproduct again of ICE and not electric vehicles. Yes this will be produced by power generation, but typically speaking most power plants are located quite far from cities and have nowhere near as much impact on air quality as car engines do.

text:
@Merit Holding, LLC Um no, algae produces natural oils as a form of energy production which is stored as lipids. We then take that and use it to produce crude oil for biofuels. Algae itself doesn't produce crude oil/petoleum.

The overwhelming scientific consensus on oil and gas formation is that it is a biotic process resulting from dead organisms being heated and squeezed to form crude oil. It is more than a theory. It is very easy to explain, once dead organisms get deposited they are not exposed to oxygen preventing aerobic bacteria from breaking it down. It then preserves and over geologic timescales will eventually be subjected to heat and pressure. Oil is less dense than rock so it flows upwards through porous rocks before it reaches an impermeable layer or cap. The oil is now trapped in its host rock or reservoir. An old well that has oil in it again simply means that new oil has flowed through the reservoir to where the well is. Or is every petroleum geologist that has ever existed wrong??? Geology was literally built off understanding sedimentary basins and knowing how and where oil will form. 

I'm assuming you mean carbon is plant food? Ok so lets use that analogy then. Water is also plant food and fundamental for photosynthesis. What happens if you over water a plant? It dies. What was once a good thing, is now a bad thing. I love eating pizza, if i eat 300kg of pizza. I'll die.

Finally the old CO2 lags temperature debate....global temperatures ARE driven by CO2. The concept that rising temperatures causes CO2 to rise is correct..... for the southern hemisphere. In the north, temperature lagged CO2 (skakun et al. 2012). About 18,000 years ago our orbital cycle shifted slightly and slightly more radiation reached the earth causing the southern ocean to warm. Increased temperature of a liquid reduces the solubility of gases in it, in this case CO2. Warming ocean temperatures started to give off CO2 (Martin et al. 2005). This initiates a positive feedback where more CO2 means more warming and more warming means more CO2. This increased warming from CO2 is what took us out of last glacial cycle into our present interglacial. 

The slight increase in warming from a change in the Milankovitch (sun) cycles has been shown time and again to not be enough to explain the amount and rate of warming observed coming out of the last glacial. CO2 initially lagged temperature rise, but it absolutely reinforced warming once the process was initiated. I love it when people use this to try and anthropogenic climate change.... this entire concept of CO2 lagging temp is not new and was published by Lorius in 1990. It isn't some conspiracy or cover up. It has been in the literature for 2 decades. 

I can keep going. I threw in some references for you to actually support my statements.

text: @Calin Campbell The catalytic converter doesn't do much for NOx. The EGR system is the main emissions control for NOx emissions in gas and diesel vehicles. These days, diesels also have the SCR system which uses a fluid to further reduce NOx. The engines still rely heavily on the EGR system to keep the fuel air mixture rich and the combustion temps low so 1) that less NOx is produced and 2) the catalyst is more effective. They don't work on diesels because diesels almost always run lean and hot (at the point of combustion).

text:
This is a huge glaring flaw making break even time only 50-30% what it should be. He figured all this with a co2 output for an average US gasoline vehicle, whereas a 2.0L turbo midsize sedan (what a sane people consider an average car, with 0-60 under 5 seconds and room for a family(Tesla size)) produces half that. A gasoline car comparable to the Nissan Leaf makes 1/3 or less co2 per mile than the "average US vehicle" These c02 figures on comparable vehicles are even less in europe, where c02 output is further restricted. His example window sticker for co2 emissions is a 5.7 L hemi RAM fullsize truck, the least efficient passenger vehicle body and engine combo available by a huge margin and it's only 20% more than the "average co2 output" he pulls from. In my honest opinion, it's about a wash for the environment at the present. All the predictions of alternative energy power grids are woefully optimistic. The power grid is already struggling to keep up. We can't even figure out how to replace the existing power grid with green alternatives, let alone make it substantially bigger for powering cars. I don't want to say electric cars are senseless, but they are a long long way from the magic bullet people want to believe in. The benefits look like 20% reduced emissions in 20 years, if we put a decent amount into renewables. Which might not even beat the improvements on existing ICE tech. The sad truth of this is, it's really all about corporations and investment, not the environment. Oil industry might be evil, but at least we have some grasp of it, who knows what we'll be getting next. The one downside I see is that the only cost effective batteries and electronic components are pretty much coming right off the ship from China after being lightly breathed on by other nations. And people arguing lung cancer from ICE's are on pretty shaky grounds, because you don't see lung cancer of non-smokers being a giant public health problem, despite exhaust from just a couple of decades ago being hundreds of times more carcinogenic.

3rd point - yeah, i don't see how people are going to use alternative energy, mostly produced in the day time to charge their car overnight. Is every car supposed to have a charging battery pack as well?

You've made my point perfectly.   You are making the same error in logic that nearly everyone is making.

 If Seattle's power is 80% hydroelectric and 20% petroleum based, then what happens when you charge an EV?   Does the hydroelectric plant increase output?  No, it's already putting out as much power as it can.  The additional load placed on the power grid by the EV is met by petroleum power plant increasing output. 

In order for an EV not to be petroleum powered our power grid needs to have excess of non-petroleum power generating capacity that can be called on by to meet the load from the EV.   

EV's will be 100% petroleum powered until we have a power grid with an excess of non-petroleum generated power.    This is just a logical fact.

text: Well, the current Mazda 3 6 speed manual is rated at 28mpg city, 38 mpg highway, 32mpg combined. A crude estimate of the same car with SkyActive X would suggest its fuel economy would be 33-36mpg city, 45-49 mpg highway, 38-41 mpg combined. At 41 mpg combined, the average American motorist would emit ~3.7 tons of CO2 per year, which is about 32% less than what the average American motorist currently emits.  Assuming the engine is as efficient as Mazda predicts it will be, the actual fuel economy figures could still wind up being better or worse than this depending on other changes Mazda makes to the 3 (like making it lighter or heavier, reducing its internal friction, reducing its drag coefficient, etc).
author: Marmocet

text: Using the same assumptions as above, with a mild hybrid drivetrain, the Mazda 3 could easily achieve something like 47 mpg combined, which translates to 3.2 tons of CO2 emitted per year for the average American. It gets harder to say with any certainty what the engine could achieve in a full hybrid drivetrain, but 53-61 mpg would seem like a reasonable ballpark figure, again assuming no other measures are taken to improve the 3's fuel economy. In that case, the average American would be emitting ~2.8-2.4 tons of CO2 per year driving it, which would be about a 48-55% reduction relative to the current average.

text: @Nik potoƒçnik You're welcome. When it comes to emissions, manufacturing batteries emits, according to various studies I've read, between 100 and 300 kilograms of CO2 per kWh of capacity. When you factor that, as well as other manufacturing emissions associated with making a vehicle into estimates of a given vehicle's full lifecycle emissions, if BEVs are the environmentally friendlier choice, they're only marginally so in most cases. At that point, to me anyway, it then comes down to cost. In most cases, BEVs are a very expensive way to achieve a little extra CO2 emissions reduction relative to HEVs. And BEVs are also less useful because of their range limitations and the high degree to which their ranges vary depending on factors like temperature, wind, terrain and how heavily loaded the vehicle is.
author: Marmocet

text: @Nik potoƒçnik Also, you're probably right about SPCCI technology having room to improve. That seems to be true of ICEs in general. I recently saw an interview with one of the lead researchers at Argonne National Laboratory in which he said, given all the areas in which ICEs can be made more efficient, ICEVs with fuel economies of 75 mpg should be doable. If that's true, then the average American driving a vehicle as fuel efficient as that would emit 2 tons of CO2 per year. For comparison, the average American driving a Chevrolet Volt in California emits about 1.7 tons of CO2 per year, and driving a Model S emits about 1.3 tons of CO2 per year. Once embodied emissions are taken into account, the highly fuel efficient ICEV could actually have a smaller CO2 footprint over its full lifecycle. Much will depend on how emissions intensive electricity production is, and if, and to what degree, manufacturing processes can be decarbonized (although the latter would likely affect both ICEVs and BEVs). In the developing world, fuel efficient ICEVs are likely to be the lowest emissions option, and are also likely to be the most economically realistic option as well. Hence Mazda's strategy - make the thing most people are actually going to use be less emitting first, then work on other stuff.

text:
Aside from every other assumption / calculation being biased towards ICE cars, there is another consideration:  As another poster pointed out, whilst the 'small battery' (e.g. Leaf) would be compared to small ICE cars that should get better-than-average economy / emissions, the 'large battery' (e.g. Tesla P100) should be compared to large luxury sedans etc that - usually - get worse-than-average economy / emissions...

If this had been taken into account, then the differential in 'breakeven' between the small battery and large battery would be less (it would take a bit longer for the small battery to 'break even', and a bit less time for the large battery)...

But, it doesn't change the overall story / point:  The bulk of EV emissions occur once during production, whilst the bulk of ICE emissions are ongoing based on mileage - therefor, at some point the EV will have less emissions overall.  Exactly when that point occurs will vary based on a number of factors (local electrical production method, climate, mileage, etc)

The 'worst' estimate was for the P100 in West Virginia, at ~17 years - but many cars (ICE to date, but should cover EV too once there are some that old) will have a lifespan beyond that, making the EV 'cleaner' (at least for CO2) over its lifespan.

text: The data on the DOE website for electricity sources falls into the trap of using the location source of generation equal to the consuming destination. As you pointed out Idaho has a high hydro source and coal is stated as 0.14% of energy consumed. The coal data is false because Idaho's consumption of energy produced by coal is actually between 25% and 30% on any given day. This is because Idaho's coal generation is done in Wyoming and Oregon in plants partly owned by the utilities in Idaho. The DOE site's assumption of producing state equal to consuming state is wrong. It would be really hard to calculate a payback period by state because of this. Just stick to the aggregated data for the US.
author: Bob Kunz

author: Engineering Explained

text: @Engineering Explained The DOE is good at using phraseology to confuse the reader. If they had just stopped at "source" by state it would be OK. But then they assume that all electricity used in a state is also sourced in the state. I picked up on Idaho since I also live there (recognize Bogus Basin road in a lot of your shots) and I've pointed this out to others to try and clarify. If the DOE were to publish what they really wanted they would have to go to each utility and get the sources from them. As it is it appears they just count the nameplate generation capacity by state. Also, there are no utility owned coal generation plants in Idaho and only two industrial plants that use coal. So we don't have any to sell but import it from co-owned plants in Wyoming, Oregon and Nevada.

text: Heat released will be exactly equal to the heating value of the fuel used. So if the conversion efficiency of EV is higher than ICE, then EV will release less heat to the atmosphere over its life time. BUT, released heat into the atmosphere is actually not our concern. Because these heat ultimately goes into the energy balance between solar radiation and Earth's radiation, which, by making a lot of heat by driving around, is not really possible to affect such energy balance. The Earth's atmosphere heats up because of the greenhouse gas concentration, causing more solar radiation to be trapped within Earth's atmosphere, not the heat that we dump directly into the atmosphere. Lastly, the ocean gets heated up and CO2 trapped in the ocean will rush out like a can of soda, causing a runaway effect. Note that the Earth's largest CO2 storage is the ocean, not the atmosphere, and that is our biggest fear.

text: @Quintinohthree There is also more gold in the Earth's mantle than in all the treasuries; so what. Lithium is mined in significant amounts only in a few places, while whole rivers of oil are being pumped daily. I don't think anyone here really understands how much oil we actually consume, and what a scarcity disaster would follow if a significant percentage of internal combustion cars were to be replaced with lithium battery ones. Right now the electric cars are a curiosity and the world's supply of lithium is already stretched to the limits. Li-ion batteries simply can't serve as a substitute for oil, because there's enough oil to run all our cars, and there's not nearly enough lithium to replace it. Even if there were enough lithium, such extreme demand would make it a primary strategic resource of the kind petroleum is now, with political consequences. None of this would be an issue if graphene supercapacitors or some other technology was used for energy storage in cars. Also, the problem of range and charging speed remains an unsolved problem with electric cars; fast charging means lots of amps going through conduits, and this means increased probability of fire. Battery swap is unlikely to become a thing because a battery is a primary component of the vehicle, like engine in the internal combustion ones, and one is unlikely to just swap his new battery for something unknown at a charging station. Essentially, as things stand now, the problems of electric cars remain unsolved, and ecologically speaking their advantages over, for instance, natural gas internal combustion units, are highly dubious.

text:
If you think "zero emissions" is disingenuous, then I think that shows just how little you trust statements like these. Which I can understand. Greenwashing is a common thing, and it's never nice to feel deceived. The best remedy to being misled by false marketing is to learn the science behind it. I know from experience it can be a big job in the short-term, but an easy start is to learn source criticism, basic scientific theory and logical reasoning. With those tools, we can at least find some credible sources, and criticism of them, from scientists.
But of course I can agree that "zero tailpipe emissions" is a more accurate term. It's not uncommon either, but I think it's honestly just too long to catch on. Would you prefer "zero tailpipe emissions, lower lifetime emissions, still less environmental than a bike"? In my experience, we just move the question to the next item of critique. Which isn't bad in itself (curiosity and skepticism is good, in fact) - but my point is that I don't think any single phrase can explain the whole deal with electric vehicles. Change isn't easy.

text:
@Tom Higgins The thing is, wherever intermittent renewables are incorporated into a grid where the produce more than a few percent of total electricity generation, they rapidly push the price of electricity higher (see Denmark, Germany and California, for example), so from an economic perspective, renewables actually undermine the economic case for BEVs. If we ever get to a point where wind and solar are providing large proportions of our total electricity, which will mean we have frequent periods in which electricity supply is far greater than demand and wholesale electricity prices are zero to negative, fuel cell vehicles will be a better fit than BEVs.

By the way, wholesale electricity prices that are zero to negative might sound like a good thing, but it's actually the reason renewables make retail electricity prices rise. Power companies that often have to pay someone to take what they produce need to find a way to cover their costs, and they wind up doing that by charging retail customers higher rates.

text: @Whats the frequency Kenneth In the U.S., transmission losses are about 5% on average, so to get 1 kWh from the socket means 1.05 kWh needs to be generated. When charging a battery, another ~10% is lost due to charging inefficiency, so for every kWh of stored energy, ~1.17 kWh needs to be generated. On average in the US, that means ~half a kilogram of CO2 gets emitted for every kWh of energy stored in a BEV's battery.

author: wyrazowfkp

text:
@wyrazowfkp That's the charge/discharge or "roundtrip" efficiency. It's not relevant when calculating the upstream emissions of the BEV because that information is already embodied in its range per kWh of stored energy. All that's relevant there is the CO2 intensity of electricity generation, the transmission losses and the charge efficiency. 

Here's a worked example: If a car's 60 kWh battery, capable of delivering 234 miles of range, gets fully charged at a charging efficiency of 90.0% with electricity from a grid with an emissions intensity of 450g CO2/kWh and transmission losses of 5.00%, it takes 60kWh/(0.90*0.95) = 70.1kWh of electricity generation and 70.1kWh * 450g CO2/kWh = 31,545g CO2 to charge, which comes to 31,545g CO2/234 mi = 134g CO2/mi (or 83.2g CO2/km if you don't like mixing metric and imperial units).

author: Juan Miranda

text:
@Juan Miranda, no science and engineering are not the same at all. 8-(


Science and Engineering are very different undertakings.
Engineering produces things that are of actual use for people.
Science produces knowledge.


When Scientists produce this knowledge, they don't know if someone sometimes actually use it, to save the world, or to create a cool gadget, or if the knowledge simply fill reference books in science libraries (or science databases). (Go visit the science reference books of your local library...)


Engineering needs Science and Science needs Engineering, but both are TOTALLY different, in what they do and why they do it.
